revision.text:
{{lowercase title}}
'''iCE''' is the brand name used for a family of low-power [[FPGA]]s produced by [[Lattice Semiconductor]]. Parts in the family are marketed with the "world's smallest FPGA" tagline, and are intended for use in portable and battery-powered devices (such as [[mobile phone]]s),<ref name="lattice_ice_ultra-ultralite_201603">{{cite web|url=http://www.latticesemi.com/en/Products/FPGAandCPLD/iCE40Ultra.aspx |title=iCE40 Ultra / UltraLite - Lattice Semiconductor |publisher=Lattice Semiconductor |accessdate=5 April 2016 |deadurl=unfit |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160308182806/http://www.latticesemi.com/en/Products/FPGAandCPLD/iCE40Ultra.aspx |archivedate=March 8, 2016 }}</ref> where they would be used to [[Computation offloading|offload]] tasks from the device's main [[Central processing unit|processor]] or [[System on chip|SoC]]. By doing so, the main processor and its [[peripheral]]s can enter a low-power state or be powered off entirely, potentially increasing battery life.
Lattice received the iCE brand as part of its 2011 acquisition of SiliconBlue Technologies.
== History == {{Infobox company | name = SiliconBlue Technologies Corporation | logo = SiliconBlue Technologies (Post-Lattice) Logo.gif | logo_caption = The logo used by SiliconBlue following their being acquired in 2011. | type = [[Private company|Private]] | industry = [[Integrated circuit]]s | products = [[FPGA]]s | founded = {{startdate|2005|April|12}}<ref name="siliconblue_business-entity-info">{{URL|http://kepler.sos.ca.gov|California Secretary of State Business Search}}, entity number C2632216.</ref> | fate = Acquired by [[Lattice Semiconductor]] | defunct = {{enddate|2011|December|9}} | founders = {{ubl|Kapil Shankar {{small|(CEO)}}|Jack Peng {{small|(CTO)}}|Andrew Chan {{small|(VP Engineering)}}|John Birkner {{small|(Product Definition)}}}} | hq_location_city = [[Santa Clara, California]] | hq_location_country = [[United States]]<ref name="siliconblue_business-entity-info" /> | website = {{URL|https://web.archive.org/web/20120208003648/http://www.siliconbluetech.com/|www.siliconbluetech.com}} (archived copy from 2012) }}
The iCE brand was originally used by '''SiliconBlue Technologies Corporation''', a former [[Santa Clara, California]]-based [[fabless]] designer of [[integrated circuit]]s. SiliconBlue was a [[start-up company|start-up]] founded in 2005 by former employees of [[Actel]], [[Advanced Micro Devices|AMD]], Lattice, [[Monolithic Memories]], and [[Xilinx]].<ref name="siliconblue_business-entity-info" /><ref name="siliconblue_team">{{cite web | url=http://www.siliconbluetech.com/team.htm | title=SiliconBlue Team | publisher=SiliconBlue Technologies | date=2006 | accessdate=13 May 2016 | archive-date=6 December 2006 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061206215956/http://www.siliconbluetech.com/team.htm | dead-url=usurped}}</ref> Most notable among the founders was [[John Birkner]], one of the inventors of [[programmable array logic]].<ref name="computer-history-museum_pal-introduced">{{cite web | url=http://www.computerhistory.org/siliconengine/pal-user-programmable-logic-devices-introduced/ | title=1978: PAL User-Programmable Logic Devices Introduced | publisher=Computer History Museum | work=The Silicon Engine - A Timeline of Semiconductors in Computers | accessdate=13 May 2016 | archive-date=1 April 2016 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160401034348/http://www.computerhistory.org/siliconengine/pal-user-programmable-logic-devices-introduced/ | dead-url=no}}</ref>
In 2006, SiliconBlue was funded with [[US Dollar|$]]16 million in [[Series A round|"Series A"]] capital,<ref name="siliconblue_series-b-funding">{{cite press release | url=http://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20081022005376/en/SiliconBlue-Secures-24-Million-Series-B-Funding | title=SiliconBlue Secures $24 Million in Series-B Funding | publisher=SiliconBlue Technologies | date=22 October 2008 | accessdate=13 May 2016 | archive-date=13 May 2016 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160513161404/http://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20081022005376/en/SiliconBlue-Secures-24-Million-Series-B-Funding | dead-url=no}}</ref> and in June 2008 announced the iCE65 L series of devices. The devices were to be [[Semiconductor fabrication|fabricated]] on [[TSMC]]'s [[65 nanometer|65{{thinsp}}nm]] [[CMOS]] [[Semiconductor node|process node]], which SiliconBlue claimed would provide reduced power consumption compared to contemporary FPGAs from other manufacturers.<ref name="siliconblue_pr_ice65-announce" /> In October 2008, SiliconBlue raised a further $24 million in [[Series B]] capital.<ref name="siliconblue_series-b-funding"/>
In 2009, the first iCE65 L devices were shipped to customers.<ref name="siliconblue_pr_ice65l-ship"/> SiliconBlue also registered ''SiliconBlue Technologies (Hong Kong) Limited'', which remains as a [[subsidiary]] of Lattice Semiconductor.<ref name="siliconblue_hk-business-entity-info">{{URL|https://www.icris.cr.gov.hk/csci/cps_criteria.jsp|Company Particulars Search - ICRIS CSC Companies Registry}}, CR number 1330814.</ref><ref name="lattice_sec_2016_10-k_exhibit-21.1">{{cite web | url=https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/855658/000085565816000180/ex-211201510xk.htm | title=Exhibit 21.1 - Subsidiaries of the Registrant | publisher=US Securities and Exchange Commission | date=2 March 2016 | accessdate=13 May 2016}}</ref>
In 2010, the lowest-end of the iCE65 P devices was announced by SiliconBlue. The devices were claimed to be as much as 30% faster than iCE65 L devices while maintaining similar power consumption.<ref name="siliconblue_pr_ice65p-announce"/><ref name="siliconblue_ice65p-announce_eetimes">{{cite news | url=http://www.eetimes.com/document.asp?doc_id=1313688 | title=SiliconBlue unveils new series of FPGAs targeting mobile apps | work=EETimes | date=17 February 2010 | accessdate=13 May 2016 | archive-date=13 May 2016 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160513175945/http://www.eetimes.com/document.asp?doc_id=1313688 | dead-url=no}}</ref> In the June of the same year, SiliconBlue closed a $15 million Series C funding round.<ref name="siliconblue_series-c-funding">{{cite press release | url=http://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20100607006486/en/SiliconBlue-Completes-15M-Series-Preferred-Stock-Financing | title=SiliconBlue Completes $15M Series C Preferred Stock Financing | publisher=BusinessWire | date=7 June 2010 | accessdate=13 May 2016 | archive-date=13 May 2016 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160513180330/http://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20100607006486/en/SiliconBlue-Completes-15M-Series-Preferred-Stock-Financing | dead-url=no}}</ref>
In April 2011, SiliconBlue announced that it was to release new product families, code-named "Los Angeles" and "San Francisco," using a TSMC [[40 nanometer|40{{thinsp}}nm]] process node.<ref name="siliconblue_ice40-preannounce">{{cite news | url=http://www.eetimes.com/document.asp?doc_id=1270781 | title=SiliconBlue tips FPGA move to 40-nm | work=EETimes | date=5 April 2011 | accessdate=13 May 2016 | author=Clarke, Peter | archive-date=13 May 2016 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160513181135/http://www.eetimes.com/document.asp?doc_id=1270781 | dead-url=no}}</ref> The production of devices on a 40{{thinsp}}nm process node was further confirmed in June 2011, when SiliconBlue received $18 million in Series D funding to bring 40{{thinsp}}nm devices to market.<ref name="siliconblue_series-d-funding">{{cite press release | url=http://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20110629005541/en/SiliconBlue-Raises-18-Million-Series-Funding | title=SiliconBlue Raises $18 Million in Series D Funding | publisher=BusinessWire | date=29 June 2011 | accessdate=13 May 2016 | archive-date=7 May 2012 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120507071631/http://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20110629005541/en/SiliconBlue-Raises-18-Million-Series-Funding | dead-url=no}}</ref><ref name="siliconblue_series-d-funding_techcrunch">{{cite news | url=https://techcrunch.com/2011/06/29/siliconblue-scores-18-million-in-series-d-funding/ | title=SiliconBlue Scores $18 Million in Series D Funding | work=TechCrunch | date=29 June 2011 | accessdate=13 May 2016 | author=Wauters, Robin | archive-date=10 March 2016 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160310073750/http://techcrunch.com/2011/06/29/siliconblue-scores-18-million-in-series-d-funding/ | dead-url=no}}</ref> The iCE40 product family was officially released in July 2011.<ref name="siliconblue_ice40_launch">{{cite news | url=http://www.eetimes.com/document.asp?doc_id=1316702 | title=SiliconBlue launches 40nm mobileFPGA family (code name "Los Angeles") | work=EETimes | date=11 July 2011 | accessdate=13 May 2016 | author=Maxfield, Clive | archive-date=13 May 2016 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160513184640/http://www.eetimes.com/document.asp?doc_id=1316702 | dead-url=no}}</ref>
On 9 December 2011, SiliconBlue Technologies was acquired by Lattice Semiconductor in a $63.2 million cash buyout. As part of this buyout, Lattice received the iCE brand, manufacturing capabilities with TSMC, and a licence for various patents from Kilopass Technologies, including for its XPM [[one-time programmable]] (OTP) memory technology.<ref name="lattice_sec_2012_10-k">{{cite book | url=https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/855658/000085565812000035/a201110-k12x31x2011.htm | title=Form 10-K - Lattice Semiconductor Corporation | publisher=US Securities and Exchange Commission | year=2012}}</ref>{{rp|15, 8, 11}}
In April 2012, Lattice announced that the iCE65 families would be discontinued.<ref name="lattice_pcn_08b-12" /> The iCE40 LP and HX device families entered volume production the following month.<ref name="lattice_pr_ice40-launch" /> The iCE40 LP family won the [[Electronics Weekly#Elektra Awards|Elektra]] ''Digital Semiconductor Product of the Year'' award for 2012.<ref name="elektra-awards_winners_2012" />
In July 2014, the iCE40 Ultra family was announced.<ref name="lattice_pr_ice40-ultra-launch" />
In February 2015, Lattice launched the iCE40 UltraLite device family. The devices in this family are claimed to operate at 30% less power than those of unspecified competitors, and are claimed to be the world's smallest FPGAs, being available in 1.4×1.4{{thinsp}}mm [[Semiconductor package|packages]].<ref name="lattice_pr_ice40-ultralite-launch" /> The family won the 2015 Elektra ''Digital Semiconductor Product of the Year'' award.<ref name="elektra-awards_winners_2015" />
In December 2016, Lattice launched the iCE40 UltraPlus device family. UltraPlus devices provide additional memory, additional processing elements, and support for newer interfaces and protocols compared to previous iCE40 Ultra/UltraLite devices.<ref name="lattice_pr_ice40-ultraplus-launch"/><ref name="eetimes_ice40-ultraplus-launch"/>
{{clear}}
== Architecture ==
[[File:Lattice iCE40LP-HX1K arch.png|235x225px|thumb|The architecture of iCE40 LP and HX1K devices.]]
{{seealso|FPGA#Technical design|FPGA#Architecture}}
iCE65 and iCE40 devices are constructed as an array of ''programmable logic blocks'' (PLBs), where a PLB is a block of eight [[Logic block|logic cells]]. Each logic cell consists of a four-input [[lookup table]] (sometimes called a 4-LUT or LUT4) with the output connected to a [[Flip-flop (electronics)#D flip-flop|D flip-flop]] (a 1-[[bit]] storage element). Within a PLB, each logic cell is connected to the following and preceding cell by carry logic, intended to improve the performance of constructs such as [[Adder (electronics)|adders]] and [[subtractor]]s. Interspersed with PLBs are blocks of [[Random access memory|RAM]], each four [[kilobit]]s in size. The number of RAM blocks varies depending on the device.<ref name="lattice_ds_1040-v3.2" />{{rp|pages=. 2-1 to 2-3}}<ref name="lattice_ds_ice65l-v2.42" />{{rp|pages=. 5–9}}
Compared to LUT6-based architectures (such as [[Xilinx]] 7-series devices and [[Altera]] [[Stratix]] devices), a LUT4-based device is unable to implement as-complex [[logic function]]s with the same number of logic cells. For example, a logic function with seven inputs could be implemented in eight LUT4s or two LUT6s.
iCE devices use volatile [[Static random-access memory|SRAM]] to store configuration data. As a result, the data must be loaded onto the device each time power is lost. All iCE devices support loading configuration data from a [[Programmer (hardware)|programmer]], from an external [[flash memory]] chip, or, with the exception of iCE40 ''LM'' devices,<ref name="lattice_ice-lp-hx-lm_201603" /> from a so-called NVCM, or non-volatile configuration memory. The NVCM is a one-time-programmable (OTP) memory integrated into the FPGA to negate the need for an external memory chip. Lattice claims that using the NVCM can improve design security by making [[reverse engineering]] more difficult.<ref name="lattice_tn_1248-v2.8">{{cite book | title=Lattice TN1248 - iCE40 Programming and Configuration v2.8 | publisher=Lattice Semiconductor | year=2015}}</ref>
The [[GPIO|I/O pins]] on iCE devices are separated into up to four banks. On some devices each bank has its own [[IC power-supply pin|power-supply pin]] (labelled V<sub>CCIO</sub>), allowing the [[Logic level|logic-high]] voltage level of the I/O bank to be adjusted.<ref name="lattice_ds_1040-v3.2" />{{rp|2-7}} Configurable I/O voltage levels are used by iCE devices to allow support for multiple interface standards with voltage levels between 1.8{{thinsp}}V and 3.3{{thinsp}}V, such as [[LVDS]].<ref name="lattice_ds_1040-v3.2" />{{rp|3-1}} iCE65 devices also listed being able to support [[Stub Series Terminated Logic|SSTL]] through this method.<ref name="lattice_ds_ice65l-v2.42" />{{rp|11}}
{{clear}}
== Development ==
{{mainarticle|Hardware description language|Design flow (EDA)}}
iCE FPGAs, as with most FPGAs and [[CPLD]]s, are typically designed for using a hardware description language (or HDL), which describes an electronic circuit. Lattice Diamond, the [[integrated development environment|IDE]] provided by Lattice for developing on their FPGAs, supports the [[VHDL]] and [[Verilog]] languages, as well as the [[EDIF]] format.<ref name="lattice_diamond_201603">{{cite web|url=http://latticesemi.com/en/Products/DesignSoftwareAndIP/FPGAandLDS/LatticeDiamond.aspx |title=Lattice Diamond - Lattice Semiconductor |publisher=Lattice Semiconductor |accessdate=8 April 2016 |deadurl=unfit |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160325211520/http://latticesemi.com/en/Products/DesignSoftwareAndIP/FPGAandLDS/LatticeDiamond.aspx |archivedate=March 25, 2016 }}</ref>
=== Open source ===
The details of a specific FPGA's [[bitstream]] format (which defines how the internal elements of the FPGA are connected and interact with each other) are not usually published by FPGA vendors. This means that, generally, an engineer creating a design for an FPGA must use the tools provided by the FPGA's manufacturer.
In December 2015, at [[32C3]],<ref name="32c3_icestorm">{{cite web|url=https://events.ccc.de/congress/2015/Fahrplan/events/7139.html |title=Schedule 32. Chaos Communication Congress |publisher=Chaos Computer Club |accessdate=8 April 2016 |deadurl=unfit |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160108202522/https://events.ccc.de/congress/2015/Fahrplan/events/7139.html |archivedate=January 8, 2016 }}</ref> a [[toolchain]] consisting of ''Yosys'' (Verilog synthesis [[Compiler#Frontend|frontend]]), ''Arachne-pnr'' ([[place and route]] and bitstream generation), and ''icepack'' ([[plain text]]-to-binary bitstream conversion) tools was presented by Clifford Wolf, one of the two developers (along with Mathias Lasser) of the toolchain. The toolchain is notable for being one of, if not the only, fully open-source toolchains for FPGA development. At the same December 2015 presentation, Wolf also demonstrated a [[RISC-V]] SoC design built using the open-source toolchain and running on an iCE40 ''HX8K'' device. As of April 2016, the toolchain supports iCE40 ''LP1K'', ''LP4K'', ''LP8K'', and ''HX'' devices.<ref name="cliffordwolf_icestorm_201603">{{cite web|url=http://www.clifford.at/icestorm/ |title=Project IceStorm |publisher=Clifford Wolf |date=17 January 2016 |accessdate=8 April 2016 |deadurl=unfit |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304202757/http://www.clifford.at/icestorm/ |archivedate=March 4, 2016 }}</ref>
== List of iCE devices ==
=== iCE65 (65 nm) ===
The ''iCE65'' name was used by SiliconBlue Technologies for the devices it designed for a 65{{thinsp}}nm process node. Following the acquisition of SiliconBlue in 2011, the name was used by Lattice Semiconductor until the family was discontinued in April 2012.<ref name="lattice_pcn_08b-12">{{cite book | title=PCN# 08B-12: Notification of Intent to Discontinue the iCE65 Product Family | publisher=Lattice Semiconductor | year=2012}}</ref>
==== iCE65 L ====
{| class="wikitable floatright" |+ style="font-weight: bold; margin-bottom: 0.25em;" | iCE65 Parts |- ! Series ! Device ! LEs ! RAM ! PLLs ! Max. I/Os |- | rowspan="4" | iCE65 L | L01 | {{right}} 1280 | {{right}} 64{{thinsp}}kbit | rowspan="4" {{n/a}} | {{right}} 95 |- | L04 | {{right}} 3520 | {{right}} 80{{thinsp}}kbit | {{right}} 176 |- | L08 | {{right}} 7680 | {{right}} 128{{thinsp}}kbit | {{right}} 222 |- | L16 | {{right}} 16{{thinsp}}896 | {{right}} 384{{thinsp}}kbit | {{unknown}} |- | rowspan="4" | iCE65 P | P04 | {{right}} 3520 | {{right}} 80{{thinsp}}kbit | {{ya|text=1}} | {{right}} 174 |- | P08 | {{right}} 7680 | {{right}} 128{{thinsp}}kbit | {{ya|text=2}} | {{unknown}} |- | P12 | {{right}} 12{{thinsp}}160 | {{right}} 160{{thinsp}}kbit | {{ya|text=2}} | {{unknown}} |}
The '''iCE65 L''' series of devices was intended for low-power applications and handheld devices. The series was first announced in mid 2008,<ref name="siliconblue_pr_ice65-announce">{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/idUS123525+02-Jun-2008+BW20080602 |title=SiliconBlue Pioneers New FPGA Technology for Handheld, Ultra-Low Power Applications |publisher=SiliconBlue Technologies |date=2 June 2008 |accessdate=9 April 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160409075954/https://www.reuters.com/article/idUS123525%2B02-Jun-2008%2BBW20080602 |archivedate=9 April 2016 |df= }}</ref> and first shipped to volume customers in early 2009.<ref name="siliconblue_pr_ice65l-ship">{{cite web|url=http://www.eetimes.com/document.asp?doc_id=1311490 |title=SiliconBlue announces volume production shipments of iCE65 ultra-low-power FPGAs |publisher=EETimes |date=9 February 2009 |accessdate=6 April 2016 |deadurl=unfit |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160406165932/http://www.eetimes.com/document.asp?doc_id=1311490 |archivedate=April 6, 2016 }}</ref>
Information about a larger device in the series, the ''iCE65L16'', was listed on the SiliconBlue website in 2010,<ref name="siliconblue_ice65l_product-page">{{cite web|url=http://www.siliconbluetech.com/products/devices/pro_iCE65_L_Series_mobileFPGA.aspx |title=SiliconBlue Technologes: iCE65 L-Series |publisher=SiliconBlue Technologies |accessdate=6 April 2016 |deadurl=unfit |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100220211548/http://www.siliconbluetech.com/products/devices/pro_iCE65_L_Series_mobileFPGA.aspx |archivedate=February 20, 2010 }}</ref> but no mention is made in a 2012 revision of the L-series datasheet.<ref name="lattice_ds_ice65l-v2.42">{{cite book | title=iCE65™ Ultra Low-Power mobileFPGA™ Family Datasheet v2.42 | publisher=Lattice Semiconductor | year=2012}}</ref> It is unclear whether the device was ever produced commercially.
==== iCE65 P ====
The '''iCE65 P'''-series devices were marketed as a higher-performance version of the ''L-series'' devices, intended for use in display, memory, and [[SerDes|SERDES]] applications,<ref name="lattice_ice65-product-table">{{cite book | title=The iCE65 mobileFPGA Family Product Table v1.1 | publisher=Lattice Semiconductor }}</ref> and were announced in early 2010.<ref name="siliconblue_pr_ice65p-announce">{{cite press release|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/idUS42638+15-Feb-2010+BW20100215 |title=SiliconBlue Enables Differentiated Mobile Broadband Products with New P-Series mobileFPGA Devices |publisher=Reuters |date=15 February 2010 |accessdate=6 April 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101117204221/https://www.reuters.com/article/idUS42638%2B15-Feb-2010%2BBW20100215 |archivedate=17 November 2010 |df= }}</ref><ref name="siliconblue_ice65p-announce_eetimes"/> Three devices were listed as being part of the series but only one device, the lowest-end ''iCE65P04'', was fully specified. The latest datasheet for the family, published in 2011, lists the other two parts but does not give specifications.<ref name="siliconblue_ds_ice65p-v1.31">{{cite book | title=iCE65™ P-Series Ultra Low-Power mobileFPGA™ Family v1.31 | publisher=SiliconBlue Technologies | date=22 April 2011 }}</ref> Whether these other two devices were ever commercially produced is unclear.
{{clear}}
=== iCE40 (40 nm) ===
Lattice uses the ''iCE40'' name for its iCE-branded devices produced on a 40{{thinsp}}nm process node. The company has also used the codename ''"Los Angeles"'' in press releases. The iCE40 family was launched in July 2011 with iCE40 LP and HX parts,<ref name="siliconblue_ice40_launch"/> and was updated in July 2014 with the iCE40 Ultra parts<ref name="lattice_pr_ice40-ultra-launch" />, in February 2015 with the iCE40 UltraLite parts,<ref name="lattice_pr_ice40-ultralite-launch" /> and in December 2016 with the iCE40 UltraPlus parts.<ref name="lattice_pr_ice40-ultraplus-launch"/>
==== iCE40 Ultra, UltraLite, & UltraPlus ====
{| class="wikitable floatright" |+ style="font-weight: bold; margin-bottom: 0.25em;" | iCE40 ''Ultra'', ''UltraLite'', and ''UltraPlus'' Parts |- ! Family ! Device ! LEs ! RAM ! I²C ! SPI ! DSP ! PWM ! Max. I/Os |- | rowspan="2" | UltraLite | UL640 | {{right}} 640 | {{right}} 56{{thinsp}}kbit | {{ya|text=2}} | rowspan="2" colspan="2" {{n/a}} | {{ya}} | {{right}} 26 |- | UL1K | {{right}} 1280 | {{right}} 56{{thinsp}}kbit | {{ya|text=2}} | {{ya}} | {{right}} 26 |- | rowspan="3" | Ultra | iCE5LP1K | {{right}} 1100 | {{right}} 64{{thinsp}}kbit | {{ya|text=1}} | {{ya|text=1}} | {{ya|text=2}} | {{ya}} | {{right}} 39 |- | iCE5LP2K | {{right}} 2048 | {{right}} 80{{thinsp}}kbit | {{ya|text=2}} | {{ya|text=2}} | {{ya|text=4}} | {{ya}} | {{right}} 39 |- | iCE5LP4K | {{right}} 3520 | {{right}} 80{{thinsp}}kbit | {{ya|text=2}} | {{ya|text=2}} | {{ya|text=4}} | {{na}} | {{right}} 39 |- | rowspan="2" | UltraPlus | UP3K | {{right}} 2800 | {{right}} 1104{{thinsp}}kbit | {{ya|text=2}} | {{ya|text=2}} | {{ya|text=4}} | {{ya}} | {{right}} 21 |- | UP5K | {{right}} 5280 | {{right}} 1144{{thinsp}}kbit | {{ya|text=2}} | {{ya|text=2}} | {{ya|text=8}} | {{ya}} | {{right}} 39 |}
The '''iCE40 Ultra''', '''UltraLite''', and '''UltraPlus''' devices are intended for applications with especially low limits on available space and power, such as in [[wearable technology]] and [[smart watches]].<ref name="lattice_pr_ice40-ultra-launch">{{cite web|url=http://latticesemi.com/en/About/Newsroom/PressReleases/2015/20151201iCE40UltraWearable.aspx |title=Lattice Semiconductor Launches iCE40 Ultra™ Platform for Wearable Device Development |publisher=Lattice Semiconductor |date=1 December 2015 |accessdate=5 April 2016 |deadurl=unfit |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160331093934/http://latticesemi.com/en/About/Newsroom/PressReleases/2015/20151201iCE40UltraWearable.aspx |archivedate=March 31, 2016 }}</ref> They are offered in [[Chip-scale package|chip-scale]], [[Ball grid array|BGA]], and [[Quad Flat No-leads package|QFN]] packages, with dimensions from 1.4×1.4{{thinsp}}mm to 7×7{{thinsp}}mm. All devices in family integrate one or two [[I²C]] hard cores, with ''Ultra'' and ''UltraPlus'' devices also including hard [[Serial peripheral interface|SPI]] bus cores and [[Digital signal processor|DSP]] blocks. ''UltraLite'' devices are claimed to operate at half the static current draw of ''Ultra'' devices (35{{thinsp}}μA compared to 71{{thinsp}}μA). Most devices in the family also include a [[Pulse-width modulation|PWM]] controller, intended to be used to drive [[Infrared lamp|IR]] or [[Light-emitting diode#RGB|RGB LED]]s.<ref name="lattice_tn_1288-v1.1">{{cite book | title=TN 1288 - iCE40 LED Driver Usage Guide | publisher=Lattice Semiconductor | year=2014}}</ref>{{rp|5}}
Lattice launched the ''Ultra'' family in mid 2014,<ref name="lattice_pr_ice40-ultra-launch" /> and the ''UltraLite'' family in early 2015.<ref name="lattice_pr_ice40-ultralite-launch">{{cite web|url=http://latticesemi.com/en/About/Newsroom/PressReleases/2015/201502UltraLite.aspx |title=Lattice Semiconductor’s New iCE40 UltraLite Device Enables OEMs to Accelerate Time-to-Market of Feature-Rich Mobile Devices |publisher=Lattice Semiconductor |date=3 February 2015 |accessdate=5 April 2016 |deadurl=unfit |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160331095525/http://latticesemi.com/en/About/Newsroom/PressReleases/2015/201502UltraLite.aspx |archivedate=March 31, 2016 }}</ref> In 2015, the ''UltraLite'' family won the Elektra ''Digital Semiconductor Product of the Year'' award.<ref name="elektra-awards_winners_2015">{{cite web|url=http://www.elektraawards.co.uk/elektraawards2016/2015-winners |title=2015 Winners :: Elektra Awards |publisher=Electronics Weekly |accessdate=5 April 2016 |deadurl=unfit |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160405194156/http://www.elektraawards.co.uk/elektraawards2016/2015-winners |archivedate=April 5, 2016 }}</ref>
In September 2016, the [[Apple, Inc.|Apple]] [[iPhone 7]] was released and made use of an iCE5LP4K device.<ref name="chipworks_iphone-7-teardown">{{cite web | url=http://www.chipworks.com/about-chipworks/overview/blog/apple-iphone-7-teardown | title=Apple iPhone 7 Teardown {{!}} Chipworks | publisher=Chipworks Inc. | date=15 September 2016 | accessdate=17 September 2016 | archive-date=16 September 2016 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160916230725/http://www.chipworks.com/about-chipworks/overview/blog/apple-iphone-7-teardown}}</ref>
In December 2016, Lattice launched the ''UltraPlus'' family intended for [[distributed processing]] and so-called "mobile [[heterogeneous computing]]." The devices include a 1{{nbsp}}Mbit (4×256{{nbsp}}kbit) single-port RAM (compare with [[dual-ported RAM]]), additional DSP processing elements, and support for additional interfaces, such as [[MIPI Alliance|MIPI]] I3C, D-PHY, and Virtual GPIO.<ref name="lattice_pr_ice40-ultraplus-launch">{{cite press release | url=http://www.latticesemi.com/About/Newsroom/PressReleases/2016/20161212NewiCE40UltraPlusDevices.aspx | title=New iCE40 UltraPlus Devices from Lattice Semiconductor Accelerate Customer Innovation in Smartphones and IoT Edge Devices | publisher=Lattice Semiconductor | date=12 December 2016 | accessdate=28 May 2017 | archive-date=28 May 2017 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170528152559/http://www.latticesemi.com/About/Newsroom/PressReleases/2016/20161212NewiCE40UltraPlusDevices.aspx | deadurl=no}}</ref><ref name="eetimes_ice40-ultraplus-launch">{{cite news | url=http://www.eetimes.com/document.asp?doc_id=1331054 | title=Lattice introduces iCE40 UltraPlus high-performance low-power FPGAs | work=EETimes | date=22 December 2016 | accessdate=28 May 2017 | author=Maxfield, Max | archive-date=30 January 2017 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170130132650/http://www.eetimes.com/document.asp?doc_id=1331054 | deadurl=no}}</ref>
{{clear}}
==== iCE40 LP & LM ====
{| class="wikitable floatright" |+ style="font-weight: bold; margin-bottom: 0.25em;" | iCE40 ''LP'' and ''LM'' Parts |- ! Family ! Device ! LEs ! RAM ! I²C ! SPI ! PLLs ! Max. I/Os |- | scope="row" rowspan="5" | LP | LP384 | {{right}} 384 | {{na}} | rowspan="5" colspan="2" {{n/a}} | {{na}} | {{right}} 39 |- | LP640 | {{right}} 640 | {{right}} 32{{thinsp}}kbit | {{na}} | {{right}} 11 |- | LP1K | {{right}} 1280 | {{right}} 64{{thinsp}}kbit | {{ya|text=1}} | {{right}} 97 |- | LP4K | {{right}} 3520 | {{right}} 80{{thinsp}}kbit | {{ya|text=2}} | {{right}} 180 |- | LP8K | {{right}} 7680 | {{right}} 128{{thinsp}}kbit | {{ya|text=2}} | {{right}} 180 |- | rowspan="3" | LM | LM1K | {{right}} 1100 | {{right}} 64{{thinsp}}kbit | {{ya|text=2}} | {{ya|text=2}} | {{ya|text=1}} | {{right}} 39 |- | LM2K | {{right}} 2048 | {{right}} 80{{thinsp}}kbit | {{ya|text=2}} | {{ya|text=2}} | {{ya|text=1}} | {{right}} 39 |- | LM4K | {{right}} 3520 | {{right}} 80{{thinsp}}kbit | {{ya|text=2}} | {{ya|text=2}} | {{ya|text=1}} | {{right}} 39 |}
The '''iCE40 LP''' (low power) and '''LM''' (low power with [[Semiconductor intellectual property core#Hard cores|hard IP]]) parts are intended for use in battery-powered devices as [[hardware accelerator]]s and I/O [[port expander]]s, and for use in the same applications as ''iCE40 Ultra'' and ''UltraLite'' parts. Compared to the ''Ultra'' parts, ''LP'' and ''LM'' parts are available in a wider range of [[Footprint (electronics)|footprints]], offer a greater number of resources (I/O pins, embedded RAM, and logic elements), but consume more power.<ref name="lattice_ice-lp-hx-lm_201603">{{cite web|url=http://latticesemi.com/Products/FPGAandCPLD/iCE40.aspx |title=iCE40 LP/HX/LM - Lattice Semiconductor |publisher=Lattice Semiconductor |accessdate=6 April 2016 |deadurl=unfit |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160325005933/http://latticesemi.com/Products/FPGAandCPLD/iCE40.aspx |archivedate=March 25, 2016 }}</ref>
''LP'' devices differ from the ''Ultra'' devices in that they do not include hard IP cores. Instead, any interface logic must be implemented in the FPGA fabric. This is generally less preferable, as so-called "soft cores" are less power-efficient than hard cores, and often are unable to operate at the same [[Clock rate|frequencies]]. A soft core also reduces the number of logic cells available to the application. ''LM'' devices integrate two I²C and two SPI hard cores, as well as two strobe generators. Most ''LP'' and ''LM'' devices integrate one or two phase-locked loops.
The families were launched in mid 2011 and entered volume production in mid 2012.<ref name="siliconblue_ice40_launch"/><ref name="lattice_pr_ice40-launch">{{cite web|url=http://latticesemi.com/en/About/Newsroom/PressReleases/2012/201205ProductionReleaseOfiCE40LosAngeles.aspx |title=Lattice Announces Production Release Of iCE40 Los Angeles LP-Series And HX-Series mobileFPGA Device Families |publisher=Lattice Semiconductor |date=8 May 2012 |accessdate=5 April 2016 |deadurl=unfit |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160331092704/http://latticesemi.com/en/About/Newsroom/PressReleases/2012/201205ProductionReleaseOfiCE40LosAngeles.aspx |archivedate=March 31, 2016 }}</ref> They won the Elektra ''Digital Semiconductor Product of the Year'' award for 2012.<ref name="elektra-awards_winners_2012">{{cite web|url=http://www.elektraawards.co.uk/elektraawards2016/2012-winners |title=2012 Winners :: Elektra Awards |publisher=Electronics Weekly |accessdate=6 April 2016 |deadurl=unfit |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160406113851/http://www.elektraawards.co.uk/elektraawards2016/2012-winners |archivedate=April 6, 2016 }}</ref> In 2015, it was announced that [[ZTE]] would use ''LM'' devices to provide [[sensor hub]] and infrared [[remote control]] functionality in its Star 2 smartphone.<ref name="lattice_pr_zte-ice40-use">{{cite web | url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/or-lattice-semiconductor-idUKnBw235326a+100+BSW20150623 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160406114428/http://uk.reuters.com/article/or-lattice-semiconductor-idUKnBw235326a+100+BSW20150623 | dead-url=yes | archive-date=6 April 2016 | title=ZTE Chooses Lattice Semiconductor for Feature Differentiation and Integration on Star 2 Smartphone | publisher=Reuters | date=23 June 2015 | accessdate=6 April 2016}}</ref>
{{clear}}
==== iCE40 HX ====
{| class="wikitable floatright" |+ style="font-weight: bold; margin-bottom: 0.25em;" | iCE40 ''HX'' Parts |- ! Device ! LEs ! RAM ! PLLs ! Static current ! Max. I/Os |- | HX1K | {{right}} 1280 | {{right}} 64{{thinsp}}kbit | {{ya|text=1}} | {{right}} 296{{thinsp}}μA | {{right}} 98 <!--| BGA-132 {{small|(8×8{{thinsp}}mm)}}{{br}}QFP-100 {{small|(14×14{{thinsp}}mm)}}{{br}}QFP-144 {{small|(20×20{{thinsp}}mm)}}{{br}}--> <!--| {{right}} 97{{br}}74{{br}}98--> |- | HX4K | {{right}} 3520 | {{right}} 80{{thinsp}}kbit | {{ya|text=2}} | {{right}} 1140{{thinsp}}μA | {{right}} 109 <!--| BGA-132 {{small|(8×8{{thinsp}}mm)}}{{br}}QFP-144 {{small|(20×20{{thinsp}}mm)}}{{br}}--> <!--| {{right}} 97{{br}}109--> |- | HX8K | {{right}} 7680 | {{right}} 128{{thinsp}}kbit | {{ya|text=2}} | {{right}} 1140{{thinsp}}μA | {{right}} 208 <!--| BGA-132 {{small|(8×8{{thinsp}}mm)}}{{br}}BGA-225 {{small|(7×7{{thinsp}}mm)}}{{br}}BGA-256 {{small|(14×14{{thinsp}}mm)}}{{br}} --> <!--| {{right}} 97{{br}}180{{br}}208--> |}
The '''iCE40 HX''' devices are intended for high-performance applications. Compared to ''iCE40 LP'' and ''Ultra'' devices, they offer lower maximum [[Propagation delay#Electronics|propagation delay]] (7.30{{thinsp}}[[Nanosecond|ns]] versus 9.00–9.36{{thinsp}}ns),<ref name="lattice_ds_1040-v3.2">{{cite book | title=DS1040 - iCE40 LP/HX Family Data Sheet v3.2 | publisher=Lattice Semiconductor | year=2015}}</ref>{{rp|3-13,3-15}} and more I/O pins. ''HX'' series devices consume significantly more static power and are available only in significantly larger footprints compared to ''Ultra'' and ''LP'' parts (7×7{{thinsp}}mm to 2×2{{thinsp}}cm). Similarly to the ''LP'' devices, ''HX'' parts do not provide hard IP cores, but do provide one or two phase-locked loops. Unlike other ''iCE40'' devices, the ''HX'' parts are also available in [[Quad Flat Package|QFP]] footprints.<ref name="lattice_ice-lp-hx-lm_201603" />
The ''HX'' parts were launched in mid 2011 alongside the ''LP'' parts,<ref name="siliconblue_ice40_launch"/> and entered volume production in mid 2012.<ref name="lattice_pr_ice40-launch" />
{{clear}}

revision.text:
'''IEC Technical Specification 62700: DC Power supply for notebook computer''' is an [[International Electrotechnical Commission|IEC]] specification of a common standard for external [[laptop]] computer [[AC adapter]]s. Laptops and AC adapters following this standard will have interchangeable [[Power supply unit (computer)|power supplies]], which will enable easy reuse of used power supplies (thereby reducing [[electronic waste]]) and make buying a new compatible power supply for a laptop simpler.<ref name="iec_news">{{cite web|url=http://www.iec.ch/newslog/2013/nr2713.htm|title=Major milestone: single charger for notebook computers will significantly reduce e-waste|publisher=IEC}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://arstechnica.com/information-technology/2013/12/one-charger-to-power-nearly-every-laptop-coming-from-standards-group/|title=IEC presses for single charger specification for notebook computers|publisher=EDN Europe}}</ref>
The specification was published on {{date|2014-02-06}}.<ref>http://webstore.iec.ch/webstore/webstore.nsf/artnum/049207</ref>
== Alternatives == Despite being an industry open organization with open participation, the standard has been criticized by some for not being openly available for review. Some alternatives include: * IEEE has a proposed standard [[Universal Power Adapter for Mobile Devices]] for laptops and other devices. * The USB Promoters Group's [[Universal Serial Bus#PD|USB Power Delivery]] ("PD") specification supports up to 100 W, and is intended to be able to power laptops. * [[EmPower (aircraft power adapter)]] is intended for passenger aircraft.
==See also== * [[Common External Power Supply]] - EN 62684 / IEC 62684, a widely adopted 2010 European specification standardizing smartphone power supplies on the USB Battery charging specification and USB connectors.
==References== {{reflist}}
== External links == * [http://webstore.iec.ch/webstore/webstore.nsf/artnum/049207 IEC/TS 62700 ed1.0 - DC power supply for notebook computers] at the IEC Webstore * IEC working groups for IEC 62700: [http://www.iec.ch/dyn/www/f?p=103:14:0::::FSP_ORG_ID,FSP_LANG_ID:7629,25 Project] [http://www.iec.ch/dyn/www/f?p=103:14:0::::FSP_ORG_ID,FSP_LANG_ID:10972,25 Maintenance] * {{IEC|62700}} {{List of International Electrotechnical Commission standards}}{{DC power delivery standards}}
[[Category:Power supplies]] [[Category:IEC standards|#62700]] [[Category:Electronics and the environment]]

ISO 24617-1:2009, '''ISO-TimeML''' is the [[International Organization for Standardization]] [[ISO/TC37]] standard for time and event markup and annotation.<ref>http://www.tc37sc4.org/new_doc/iso_tc37_sc4_N385_wg2_iso-timeml_provo2007_beamer_utf8.pdf. Retrieved 2010-5-3.</ref> The scope is standardization of principles and methods relating to the annotation of temporal events in the contexts of electronic documentation and language.
==Objectives of ISO-TimeML== The goals of ISO-TimeML are to provide a common model for the creation and use of temporal and event annotation, as a means of managing time-related data within documents, and to enable later categorization and data extraction with use of this meta-data.
==History of ISO-TimeML== ISO-TimeML was presented to the ISO for consideration as a standard in August 2007. In this presentation, the preliminaries of ISO-TimeML were outlined, and potential applications were examined.<ref>http://www.tc37sc4.org/new_doc/iso_tc37_sc4_N385_wg2_iso-timeml_provo2007_beamer_utf8.pdf. Retrieved 2010-5-15.</ref> In the following year, revisions were made to ISO-TimeML as the standard transitioned from a New Project (NP) to a Working Project (WP).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tc37sc4.org/new_doc/iso_tc37_sc4_N471_rev01_SemAFTime_meetingNotes_Marrakech2008.pdf|title=Invincible Internet Security - Internet Addiction|author=|date=|website=www.tc37sc4.org|accessdate=2 April 2018}}</ref> The ISO-TimeML voting period began in October 2008 and was approved as an international standard by March 2009.
==Current stage== {{Empty section|date=July 2010}}
==ISO-TimeML as one of the members of the ISO/TC37 family of standards==
The ISO/TC37 standards are currently elaborated as high level [[specifications]] and deal with [[word segmentation]] (ISO 24614), [[annotations]] (ISO 24611 a.k.a. MAF, ISO 24612 a.k.a. LAF, ISO 24615 a.k.a. SynAF, and ISO 24617-1 a.k.a. SemAF/Time), [[feature structures]] (ISO 24610), multimedia containers (ISO 24616 a.k.a. MLIF), and [[lexicons]] (ISO 24613 a.k.a. [[Lexical Markup Framework|LMF]]). These standards are based on low level specifications dedicated to constants, namely data categories (revision of [[ISO 12620]]), [[language codes]] ([[ISO 639]]), [[scripts codes]] ([[ISO 15924]]), [[country codes]] ([[ISO 3166]]) and [[Unicode]] ([[ISO 10646]]).
The two level organization forms a coherent family of standards with the following common and simple rules: * the high level specification provides structural elements that are adorned by the standardized constants; * the low level specifications provide standardized constants as metadata.
==Work group members== Joint work between ISO/TC 37/SC 4/WG 2 (TDG 3) and the TimeML Working Group that was agreed on at the TDG 3 and LIRICS Working Group Meeting, USC/ISI, Marina del Rey, CA, U.S.A., 2006-04-20/21/22.
Proposed Project Leaders and Editors: *James Pustejovsky (editor) *Kiyong Lee (co-editor) *Harry Bunt *Branmir Boguraev *Nancy Ide
==Further reading== * [[TimeML]]
==External links== *[http://www.timeml.org TimeML Specification Language] *[http://www.cs.brandeis.edu/ Brandeis University Computer Science Department]
==References== <references/>

'''Intermodalics''' is a software engineering and robotics company headquartered in [[Leuven|Leuven, Belgium]].
It has been recognized as one of the most promising innovative companies of Belgium.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Probst|first=Laurent|date=28 October 2015|title=Advanced Manufacturing, Measurement technologies and robotics, Case study 4|url=http://ec.europa.eu/DocsRoom/documents/13409/attachments/1/translations/en/renditions/pdf|journal=European Commission Business Innovation Observatory|volume=|pages=1–19|ref=Ares(2015)4645626|via=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://trends.knack.be/economie/ondernemen/intermodalics-schrijft-intelligente-software-voor-robots/article-normal-527793.html|title=Intermodalics schrijft intelligente software voor robots|date=2015-01-23|access-date=2017-06-29}}</ref><ref name=":0" /><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.demorgen.be/technologie/perfecte-uitzendkracht-de-robot-bcabf53a/|title=Perfecte uitzendkracht: de robot|last=SOENENS|first=DOMINIQUE|work=De Morgen|access-date=2017-06-29|language=nl-NL}}</ref>
==Company History== Intermodalics<ref>{{cite web|title=Intermodalics|url=http://www.intermodalics.eu/|accessdate=2017-06-26}}</ref> was co-founded in [[Leuven|Leuven, Belgium]] in 2011 by Dr. Peter Soetens and Dr. Ruben Smits as CEO and CTO respectively.
The company find its roots in the [https://www.mech.kuleuven.be/en/pma/research/robotics Robotics Research Group] of [[KU Leuven]], focusing on highly innovative projects.
It is very active in the Open Source community,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.osrfoundation.org/team/intermodalics/|title=Intermodalics (Open Source Robotics Foundation)|last=|first=|date=|website=www.osrfoundation.org|language=en-US|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-06-29}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://rosindustrial.org/news/2016/2/23/ros-bridges-for-common-field-busses|title=ROS Bridges for Common Field Busses|work=ROS-Industrial|access-date=2017-06-29|language=en-US}}</ref> most notably as developer and maintainer of the Open Robot Control Software project [http://www.orocos.org Orocos], a [[Free software|Free Software]] toolkit for [[Real-time computing|realtime]] robot arm and [[machine tool]] control.
During the summer of 2014 Intermodalics co-developed the first Neopter - a commercial drone [[Swarm robotics|swarm]] for light shows - for the attraction park [[Puy du Fou|Le Puy du Fou]] in [[France]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.neopter.com/#les-neopters|title=Neopter®|last=Douny|website=Neopter®|language=fr|access-date=2017-06-26}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.intermodalics.eu/news/our-software-controls-50-autonomous-drones|title=Our software controls 50 autonomous drones {{!}} Intermodalics - Robots, Software, Applications|website=www.intermodalics.eu|language=en|access-date=2017-06-26}}</ref>
In January, 2015 the company announced a partnership with [[Google]] related to the Google [[Project Tango]] project.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.intermodalics.eu/news/intermodalics-working-project-tango-team|title=Intermodalics working with the Project Tango Team|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
That same year, the company launched Pick-it.,<ref>{{cite web|title=Pick-it|url=https://pickit3d.com/|accessdate=2017-06-26}}</ref> a 3D robot vision system, mostly used for material handling solutions such as robot bin-picking.
In May, 2015 Peter Soetens was named one of the 50 Belgian inspiring innovators by the Belgian financial newspaper [[De Tijd]].<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://www.tijd.be/service/50vernieuwers|title=De Tijd vijftig - De Vernieuwers {{!}} De Tijd|website=www.tijd.be|language=NL|access-date=2017-06-26}}</ref>

{{Infobox Organization |name = International Nuclear Library Network (INLN) |image = Inln.jpg |image_border = |size = 250px |caption = INLN moto |abbreviation = INLN |formation = 2005 |coordinating library = IAEA Library |type = Consortium of Nuclear Libraries/Knowledge Centres |location = Vienna, Austria (IAEA Library) |region_served = Worldwide |membership = Nuclear Libraries |status = Active |head = Giannakopoulos, Thanos |parent_organization = IAEA |website = http://inln.iaea.org |commons = United Nations }}
The '''International Nuclear Library Network (INLN)''', coordinated by the [http://www.iaea.org/OurWork/ST/NE/Library/ IAEA Library], i.e. the Library of the [[International Atomic Energy Agency]], is a consortium of nuclear libraries and knowledge centres. The Network seeks to promote the exchange of nuclear information and to strengthen strategic partnerships amongst members. The underlying strategy is twofold: first, whenever a new partner joins the network, the shared information base is enlarged; and second, the larger the information base becomes, the more attractive the network is. The 37 nuclear libraries coming from 27 countries that participate in the coalition have managed to enhance their information pool and extend their services to cover nuclear information and knowledge needs on a global scale.
== History ==
The International Nuclear Library Network was founded in 2005 by the IAEA Library and the [[Atomic Energy of Canada Limited]] (AECL) Library. In its initial years, it counted a total of five members (in addition to the initiators, the [[National Atomic Energy Commission]] of Argentina, the [[Turkish Atomic Energy Agency]] and the [[Institute of Nuclear Physics of Uzbekistan Academy of Science]]. In 2006, the [[Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation]] (ANSTO) also joined the network. In 2007, the INLN welcomed four new members: the [[China Nuclear Information Centre]], the [[Nigerian Nuclear Regulatory Authority]], the [[Obninsk State Technical University for Nuclear Power Engineering]] in the Russian Federation, and the [[Russian Association of Nuclear Science and Education]] (RANSE), thus increasing the membership to ten participants. In 2008, at the meeting of INLN Members and prospective members, during the 34th [[International Nuclear Information System]] (INIS) Liaison Officers Meeting in Vienna, a large number of nuclear libraries from around the world expressed their interest and subsequently joined the INLN: the [[Belarus INIS Center, Chair of Ecological Information Systems]], the [[Nuclear Research Institute Rez plc of Czech Republic]], the [[Egyptian Atomic Energy Authority]] (EAEA), the [[Ghana Atomic Energy Commission Library]], the [[Bhabha Atomic Research Centre]] (BARC) of India, the [[Radiological Protection Institute of Ireland]], the [[Japan Atomic Energy Agency]] (JAEA), the [[Instituto Nacional de Investigaciones Nucleares]] (ININ), [[Centro de Información y Documentación Nuclear]] (CIDN) of Mexico, the [[Centre National de l' Energie des Sciences et des Techniques Nucléaires]] (CNESTEN) of Morocco, the Korea Atomic Energy Research Institute (KAERI) at the [[University of Science and Technology (South Korea)]], the [[Vinca Nuclear Institute]] of Serbia, the Centre National des Sciences et Technologies Nucléaires [http://www.cnstn.rnrt.tn (CNSTN)] of Tunisia. In November of the same year, the Library Network of the [[National Nuclear Energy Commission|Brazilian Nuclear Energy Commission]] (Comissão Nacional de Energia Nuclear – CNEN), consisting of seven nuclear libraries, became an INLN official member. In January 2009, the [[Commissariat à l'Énergie Atomique]] (CEA) - Centre de Saclay - Centre de Ressources Documentaires joined the Network, while in 2010, the [[National Atomic Energy Commission]], the [[Norwegian Radiation Protection Authority]], and the [[Pakistan Institute of Nuclear Science & Technology]] decided to become INLN members. The Nuclear Energy Regulatory Agency of Indonesia - [[Badan Pengawas Tenaga Nuklir]] and the New Zealand [[Institute of Environmental Science and Research]] – National Radiation Laboratory are the newest members, raising the total number of Nuclear Libraries/Information Centres participating in the INLN to 37.
== Structure and function ==
[[Image:Iaea-vienna.JPG|thumb|right|IAEA headquarters (Vienna, Austria) where the IAEA Library, the INLN co-ordinating library, is located]] The International Nuclear Library Network (INLN) represents a coalition of nuclear libraries. It is designed to be an Internet-based [[library]] and [[information system]]. Its information portal is hosted by the IAEA Library and it is supported by nuclear libraries and knowledge centres worldwide; it is developed and maintained in a decentralized manner, in accordance with agreed standards. It links not only bibliographic information to full-text and audio-visual information, but also librarians, library clients and researchers to the appropriate information. Moreover, the network links nuclear information workers to each other, forming a strong community of practice, sharing knowledge, best practices and lessons learned. Among the services that INLN members provide to each other are: research services, [[interlibrary loans]], document delivery, current awareness services and any other services participating libraries wish to provide other libraries. The website offers a landing page hosting access to members' online catalogues. The success of INLN is based on its democratic structure: all participating libraries are equal partners, valued according to what they bring as practitioners in terms of information and their willingness to share, rather than on predetermined hierarchical or status levels. The actual work of the network focuses on concrete actions, bringing the right information in the right format at the right time to the right place.
== Membership ==
[[Image:Inlnservices.jpg|thumb|right|INLN services]] Membership in the INLN is open to States who are Members of the [[IAEA]] and to [[UN]] organizations. Other interested international, intergovernmental and non-governmental organizations may also join, subject to agreement of the INLN Members. Each INLN Member has the same rights and responsibilities. To apply for INLN membership, an official request is to be made by the appropriate library to the [https://www.iaea.org/resources/library/ IAEA Library], which is the coordinating library of the Network. If the requesting library is located in an IAEA Member State or belongs to an UN organization, the IAEA Library as the coordinating library will make modifications to the INLN website and inform the applicant and other participants about a new member. For other prospective participants, the coordinating library will seek approval from all existing member libraries/knowledge centres. The Coordinator, after receiving the approval from current members, will inform the applicant and the members of the outcome, and proceed with updating the INLN website.

{{Infobox company | name = International Safety Equipment Association | logo = ISEA Logo 2016.jpg | logo_size = 250px | type = Not-for-profit | genre = | foundation = [[United States]] 1933 | founder = | location_city = 1901 North Moore Street
[[Arlington, Virginia]], United States | location_country = | location = | locations = | area_served = | key_people = | industry = Safety | products = | services = Safety equipment standards and advocacy | revenue = | operating_income = | net_income = | owner = | num_employees = | parent = | divisions = | subsid = | caption = | homepage = {{URL | https://safetyequipment.org }} | footnotes = | intl = }} The '''International Safety Equipment Association''' (ISEA) is a [[trade association]] of manufacturers of [[personal protective equipment]] and other safety equipment, with its offices in [[Arlington, Virginia]]. More than 100 companies are members. The ISEA is the secretariat organization for several [[American National Standards Institute]] [[technical standards]] for products such as [[high visibility clothing]], eye protection, [[hard hat]]s, chemical and dust protection, [[Glove|hand protection]], and others; formerly this role was filled by the [[American Society of Safety Engineers]]. The organization was founded in 1933 as the '''Industrial Safety Equipment Association'''. It adopted its current name in 2000.The Tube & Pipe Journal: TPJ., Volume 11 Croydon Group, 2000, page 17 Since 2002 it has had a Web site accessible to the public and member organizations.ENR, Volume 249 Issue 13-19, McGraw Hill, 2002, page 309 In addition to technical standards development and market research, the organization also provides representation of the safety products industry to the American government. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [https://www.safetyequipment.org/ Official website] [[Category:Industry trade groups based in the United States]] [[Category:Organizations based in Arlington County, Virginia]] [[Category:Safety organizations]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=January 2013}} {{Use Irish English|date=January 2013}} {{Infobox company | name = Irish Seed Savers Association | type = [[Foundation (non-profit)|Foundation]] | foundation = 1991 | location = [[Scarriff]] | area_served = [[Republic of Ireland|Ireland]] | homepage = [http://irishseedsavers.ie/ www.irishseedsavers.ie] }}
'''Irish Seed Savers''' Association is an Irish [[non-governmental organisation]] founded in 1991. The Irish Seed Savers Association maintains a seed bank with over 600 non-commercially available varieties of seed.<ref>http://irishseedsavers.ie/about-biodiversity-conservation.php. Retrieved on 5 July 2011.</ref>
== Aims and Tasks == The Irish Seed Savers Association aims to:<ref>[http://www.heritagecouncil.ie/education/news/view-article/article/irish-seedsavers-association-website-launch/?tx_ttnews%28backPid%29=6&cHash=e97f23183b Irish Seedsavers Association Website Launch]. [[Heritage Council]]. Retrieved on 5 July 2011.</ref>
* Protect, conserve and utilise Irish plant genetic resources including rare heritage seeds, grains, vegetables and fruit. * Promote agricultural biodiversity for food security. * Educate the public on agricultural biodiversity and food security through information and workshops * Research seed, grain, vegetable and fruit varieties suited to Ireland's temperate maritime climate.
With its projects the Irish Seed Savers Association found and saved over 140 different types of Irish apple trees and 25 native Irish grains.<ref>[http://ien.ie/membership/irish-seed-saver-association/ Irish Seed Saver Association]. Irish Environmental Network. Retrieved on 5 July 2011.</ref> The Irish Seed Savers Association has a ten-acre site with purpose built facilities, native woodland and an apple orchard/nursery.<ref>[http://www.arca-net.info/pages/detail.asp?id=304860&sprache=en&organisation=Stor%20Siolta Stor Siolta]. [[Arca-Net]]. Retrieved on 5 July 2011.</ref> Irish Seed Savers Association is a network partner of the European [[SAVE Foundation]].<ref>[http://www.save-foundation.net/english/partners.htm#Partnerorganizations Our partners…] [[SAVE Foundation]]. Retrieved on 5 July 2011.</ref> Irish Seed Savers are also a member of the [[Irish Environmental Network]].
== See also == * [[SAVE Foundation]] (Safeguard for Agricultural Varieties in Europe) * [[Semperviva]] * [[ProSpecieRara]] * [[Arca-Net]]
== References == {{Reflist|2}}
== External links == * [http://irishseedsavers.ie/ Irish Seed Savers Association]
[[Category:Agricultural organisations based in Ireland]] [[Category:Sustainable agriculture]] [[Category:1991 establishments in Ireland]]

A '''jockey box''' is an insulated container containing ice and water, as well as a long coil of hollow tubing. The device is used to cool [[Drink|beverages]] being served on tap in temporary locations.<ref>{{cite web|title=Outdoor Dispensing, Jockey Box, Foam|url=https://www.homebrewtalk.com/forum/threads/outdoor-dispensing-jockey-box-foam.413435/|website=HomeBrewTalk.com - Beer, Wine, Mead, & Cider Brewing Discussion Community.|accessdate=28 January 2018}}</ref>
One end of the coiled tube in the box is fitted to the external supply of the beverage to be served (often moved from the supply container by [[Partial pressure|gas pressure]], as in the case of [[Keg beer|beer in kegs]], and the other end is attached to taps for serving the beverage, which are often integrated into the box itself. Filling the jockey box with ice and water cools the coiled tubing, and when the beverage flows through the tube, the beverage is cooled to a temperature just above [[Freezing|freezing]], even if it was at [[room temperature]] before it entered the box. This allows cold drinks to be served on tap in temporary and outdoor venues.<ref>{{cite web|title=All About Jockey Boxes|url=https://www.micromatic.com/draft-keg-beer-edu/about-jockey-boxes-aid-118.html|website=www.micromatic.com|accessdate=28 January 2018}}</ref>
Apart from the coil and taps, the jockey box resembles a [[cool box]]. Some jockey boxes force the liquid through a solid cold plate rather than a coil of tubing<ref>{{cite web|title=Build an Electric Draft Jockey Box: Projects - Brew Your Own|url=https://byo.com/project/build-an-electric-draft-jockey-box-projects/|website=Brew Your Own|accessdate=28 January 2018}}</ref> (see Alternative Portable Cooler Dispensers below).
A [[glove compartment]] is also sometimes referred to as a "jockey box," especially in the U.S. Upper Rocky Mountain states.<ref>{{cite web|title=Jockey Box|url=https://www.waywordradio.org/jockey-box/|website=A Way with Words|accessdate=28 January 2018|date=25 June 2011}}</ref>
==Alternative Portable Cooler Dispensers==
In the coil cooler, a stainless steel coil is covered with water and ice, in which the liquid is made run through. At the contact with the cold coil, the beverage becomes cold. On the flip side, the cold plate works making the beverage run across an ice covered aluminum cold plate. When the plate makes contact with the ice, the plate become cold provoking the liquid that runs over it becomes cold too.<ref>{{cite web|title=Cold Plate Coolers vs. Coil Coolers|url=https://www.micromatic.com/beer-questions/party-cooler-coil-cold-plate|website=www.micromatic.com|accessdate=28 January 2018}}</ref>
A portable ice maker and water dispenser is a device that produces ice, and release chill water by a small in-house generator. Depending on the size, some of them require a water line connection, but most of them only needs to have water deposited in its container.<ref>{{cite web|title=Portable Ice Makers|url=https://chillicemaker.com/%20portable%20ice%20maker/|accessdate=28 January 2018}}</ref>
==References== <references />
