Cost !! Special Notes |- | [[Bilbao|Bilbao Renovation Project]] || [[Bilbao]] || {{Yes|Completed}} || || In the 1990s, the city began a de-industralisation process, which radically changed its image. After closing several factories and decontaminating the city's river, several megaprojects were built. A whole new [[Bilbao Airport|airport]], designed by Spanish world-famous architect [[Santiago Calatrava]], a [[Metro Bilbao|metro system]] designed by British Lord [[Norman Foster, Baron Foster of Thames Bank|Norman Foster]], a recovery of the city's old fashioned tram network changed the city's public transport system. The [[Iberdrola Tower]], which is Bilbao's tallest building, the [[Alhondiga]], the [[Zubizuri|Zubizuri bridge]] and several other significant buildings changed the city center's polluted past. The whole renovation process started because of the construction of [[Guggenheim Museum Bilbao|The Guggemheim Museum Of Bilbao]], the city's landmark and main museum. |- | [[Cuatro Torres Business Area|CTBA - Madrid Financial District]] || [[Madrid]] || {{Yes|Completed}} || est. $1,000,000,000 || A complex of four skyscrapers, each about 240 metres high, located on one of Madrid's most expensive avenua, [[Paseo de la Castellana|La Castellana]]. The towers were built on [[Real Madrid]]'s former [[Ciudad Deportiva, Madrid|Ciudad Deportiva]], and were completed in 2008. The tallest building is [[Torre Cepsa]], designed by world-famous architect [[Norman Foster]], and has a height of 249 metres, making it Spain's tallest structure. |} ====[[Sweden]]==== {| class="sortable wikitable" |- ! Project !! City/Country !! Status !! Cost !! Special Notes |- | Movement of Kiruna Centrum || [[Kiruna]] || {{Partial|Under Development}} || $2,100,000,000 || Entire project to be completed between 2020 and 2021.{{cite news|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/international/archive/2016/05/kiruna-sweden-moving/483521/|title=Sweden Is Moving an Entire City|publisher=The Atlantic|author=Linda Poon|date=19 May 2016|access-date=7 September 2017}} |- | Northvolt Gigafactory || [[Skellefteå]] & [[Västerås]] || {{Partial|Under Development}} || $4,700,000,000 || "It would make it the biggest li-ion battery factory in Europe and comparable in size to the first phase of Tesla’s [[Gigafactory 1]] in [[Nevada]], a project that Peter Carlsson, Founder and CEO of Northvolt, and Paolo Cerruti, COO of Nortvolt, both worked on."{{Cite Web |url=https://electrek.co/2017/10/19/nortvolt-battery-gigafactory-europe-sweden/ |work=Electrek |author=Lambert, Fred |date=October 19, 2017 |access-date=12 December 2017 |title=Europe’s Nortvolt battery gigafactory lands in Sweden}} |} ====[[United Kingdom]]==== {| class="sortable wikitable" |- ! Project !! City/Country !! Status !! Cost !! Special Notes |- | [[Big City Plan]] || [[Birmingham]], [[England]] || {{Partial|Under Development}} ||$17,000,000,000 || |- | [[Stratford City]] || [[London]], [[England]] || {{Partial|Under Development}} || £3,500,000,000 || Entire project to be completed by 2020. |} ===[[North America]]=== [[File:Down town markham 17.41.41.jpg|thumb|200px|right|Verclaire Gate South in Downtown Markham.]] ====[[Canada]]==== {| class="sortable wikitable" |- ! Project !! City/Country !! Status !! Cost !! Special Notes |- | [[Downtown Markham, Ontario|Downtown Markham]] || [[Markham, Ontario|Markham]], [[Ontario, Canada|Ontario]] || {{partial|Under Construction}} || $4,000,000,000 || One of the many city center projects in [[York Region]]. Scheduled for Completion in 2025. |} ====[[Mexico]] ([[Latin America]])==== {| class="sortable wikitable" |- ! Project !! City/Country !! Status !! Cost !! Special Notes |- | [[Cancún]] || [[Quintana Roo]] || {{Yes|Completed}} || || One of main tourist destinations in the world. |- | [[Santa Fe, Mexico City]] || [[Mexico City]] || {{Yes|Completed}} || || Before the city dump, today one of largest CBDs in the world. |} [[File:Brickell Key from north 20100211.jpg|thumb|200px|right|[[Brickell Key]] in Miami.]] [[File:Aria CityCenter Front.jpg|thumb|200px|right|Las Vegas [[CityCenter]], the largest set of resorts in the largest gambling center in the world.]] [[File:Battery Park City panoramic.jpg|thumb|200px|right|[[Battery Park City]]]] ====[[United States]]==== {| class="sortable wikitable" |- ! Project !! Borough/County/City/State !! Status !! Cost !! Special Notes |- | [[Pacific Park, Brooklyn|Pacific Park]] || [[Brooklyn]], [[New York City]], [[New York (state)|New York]] || {{Partial | Under Construction}} || $8,000,000,000 || The project's centerpiece, [[Barclays Center]], opened in September 2012. The project name Atlantic Yards has been renamed [[Pacific Park, Brooklyn]]. The Project is expected to be Completed by 2025 at the earliest. |- | [[Vista Tower (Chicago)|Vista Tower Project]] || [[Chicago]], [[Illinois]] || {{Partial | Under Construction}} || $1,000,000,000 || Set for Completion in 2020. |- | [[Brickell Key]] || Claughton Island, [[Miami]], [[Florida]] || {{Yes | Completed}} || $2,000,000,000+ || A [[Artificial island|man-made island]] called Claughton Island{{cite web|title=Brickell Key on Claughton Island|url=http://miami-history.com/brickell-key-on-claughton-island/}} off the mainland [[Brickell]] neighborhood of [[Miami]], [[Florida]]. |- | [[Apple Park]] || [[Cupertino]], [[California]] || {{Yes | Completed}} || $3,000,000,000+ || The "spaceship", as it is nicknamed, is Apple's new flagship headquarters (formally named Apple Campus 2). Taking the shape of a giant ring, it is expected to house over 14,000 employees. It was completed and opened in April 2017. |- | [[Encore Boston Harbor]] || [[Everett, Massachusetts|Everett]], [[Massachusetts]] || {{Partial | Under Construction}} || $2,500,000,000 || Planned to open in 2019, the casino resort property is the largest single private development in Massachusetts history. |- | [[CityCenter]] || [[Las Vegas Strip|Las Vegas]], [[Nevada]] || {{Yes | Completed}} || $11,000,000,000 || The largest privately financed development in the United States. |- | [[Wilshire Grand Center]] || [[Los Angeles]], [[California]] || {{Yes | Completed}} || $1,200,000,000 || Set to be Completed 23 June 2017. It is the [[tallest building in Los Angeles]], the [[tallest building in California]], and the tallest building west of the Mississippi at a height of 1,100 feet. |- | [[Riverside South, Manhattan|Riverside South]] || [[Manhattan]], [[New York City]], [[New York (state)|New York]] || {{Partial | Under Construction}} || $3,000,000,000 || An urban development project in the [[Lincoln Square, Manhattan|Lincoln Square]] neighborhood of the [[Upper West Side]] of [[Manhattan]], [[New York City]]. |- | [[Battery Park City]] || [[Manhattan]], [[New York City]], [[New York (state)|New York]] || {{Yes | Completed}} || $1,400,000,000+ || Mainly a residential 92-acre (37 ha) [[planned community]] at the southwestern tip of the island of [[Manhattan]] in [[New York City]], [[New York (state)|New York]], [[United States]], more than  1⁄3 of which is parkland.{{cite web|title=City Living: Battery Park City|url=http://www.amny.com/real-estate/city-living/manhattan/city-living-battery-park-city-1.6844548}} |- | [[Cornell Tech]] [[Campus]] || [[Manhattan]], [[New York City]], [[New York (state)|New York]] || {{Partial | Under Construction}} || $2,000,000,000 || Construction began in 2014 on the South end of Roosevelt Island. Phase 1 to be Completed in 2017 and Phase 2 to be Completed sometime later. |- | [[Hudson Yards Redevelopment Project]] || [[Manhattan]], [[New York City]], [[New York (state)|New York]] || {{Partial | Under Construction}} || $20,000,000,000 || A mixed-use real estate development currently being built over the 28-acre [[West Side Yard|West Side Rail Yard]]. |- | [[World Trade Center (2001–present)|Rebuilding of the World Trade Center]] || [[Manhattan]], [[New York City]], [[New York (state)|New York]] || {{Partial | Re-Construction In Progress}} || $32,000,000,000{{cite web|title=America Rebuilds: A Year at Ground Zero|url=https://www.pbs.org/americarebuilds/engineering/engineering_qfacts.html}} || Recovery from the [[September 11 attacks]]. [[One World Trade Center|One]], [[3 World Trade Center|Three]], [[4 World Trade Center|Four]], and [[7 World Trade Center|Seven]] World Trade Center Towers completed 2006-2018. [[2 World Trade Center|Two]], [[5 World Trade Center|Five]], and [[6 World Trade Center|Six]] World Trade Center Towers are either in development, currently on hold, or will never be rebuilt. |- | [[53W53]] || [[Manhattan]], [[New York City]], [[New York (state)|New York]] || {{Partial | Nearing Completion}} || $1,200,000,000 || Formerly the Tower Verre is a [[Supertall]] [[Skyscraper]] with a [[Museum]] and [[Residential]] [[Condominium]]s. Expected Completion by the end of 2018. |- | [[Comcast Technology Center]] || [[Philadelphia]], [[Pennsylvania]] || {{Partial | Nearing Completion}} || $1,500,000,000 || [[List of tallest buildings|Ninth-tallest building in the Western Hemisphere]] as well as the tallest building in the Western Hemisphere outside of [[List of tallest buildings in Manhattan|Manhattan]] and [[List of tallest buildings in Chicago|Chicago]] at a height of 1,121 feet, which is expected to be Completed in 2018. |- | [[Gigafactory 1]] || [[Reno]], [[Nevada]] || {{Partial|Under Construction}} || $5,000,000,000 || 3 Blocks (14%) of the total 21 Blocks of the factory Completed and the remaining 18 Blocks to be completed by 2020. |- | [[San Francisco Transbay development|The Transbay Redevelopment Area]] || [[San Francisco]], [[California, United States|California]] || {{Partial | Under Construction}} || $4,500,000,000 || The redevelopment of began in June 2005 and is expected to be fully Completed around 2030, includes a new [[Transbay Transit Center]] and the newly opened [[Salesforce Tower]]. The [[Salesforce Tower]] is a 1,070-foot [[Supertall]] Office [[Skyscraper]] just completed in the [[South of Market, San Francisco|South of Market]] district of downtown [[San Francisco]] at a cost of $1,100,000,000. |- | [[Bayview-Hunters Point, San Francisco|San Francisco Shipyard and Candlestick]] [[Redevelopment]] || [[San Francisco]], [[California, United States|California]] || {{Partial | Under Construction}} || $8,000,000,000 || Set to be Completed sometime after 2028. |- | [[Treasure Island Development|Treasure Island]] [[Redevelopment]] || [[San Francisco]], [[California, United States|California]] || {{Partial | In Development}} || $6,000,000,000 || Set to be Completed by 2028. |- | [[Mission Bay, San Francisco|The Mission Bay]] [[Redevelopment]] || [[San Francisco]], [[California, United States|California]] || {{Partial | Under Construction}} || $1,000,000,000 || |- | [[Parkmerced, San Francisco|Parkmerced]] || [[San Francisco]], [[California, United States|California]] || {{Partial | Under Construction}} || $1,350,000,000 || Expected to be Completed by 2035. |- | [[Washington State Convention Center]] || [[Seattle]], [[Washington (state)|Washington]] || {{Partial | Under Construction}} || $1,600,000,000 || This expansion project is expected to be Completed in 2020. |- | [[Sasol]] [[Ethane]] [[Fluid catalytic cracking|Cracker]] Complex Project || [[Westlake, Louisiana|Westlake]]-[[Mossville, Louisiana|Mossville]]-[[Lake Charles, Louisiana|Lake Charles]], [[Calcasieu Parish, Louisiana|Calcasieu Parish]], [[Louisiana]] || {{Partial | Under Construction}} || $8,900,000,000 || Sasol is constructing a world-scale petrochemical complex in Southwest Louisiana, which will roughly triple the company's chemical production capacity in the U.S. and enable it to build on its strong positions in robust and growing global chemicals markets. |} ===[[Oceania]]=== ====[[Australia]]==== {| class="sortable wikitable" |- ! Project !! City/Country !! Status !! Cost !! Special Notes |- | [[Queen's Wharf Brisbane]] || [[Brisbane]], [[Queensland]] || {{Partial|Under Construction}} || $3,000,000,000 || Integrated Resort Development located on the north bank of the [[Brisbane River]] in the [[Brisbane central business district]]. Entire project to be completed by 2024.{{cite web|title=Queen's Wharf Brisbane|url=https://queenswharfbrisbane.com.au/|publisher=Destination Brisbane Consortium}} |- | [[Barangaroo, New South Wales|Barangaroo]] || [[Sydney]], [[New South Wales]] || {{Partial|Under Construction}} || $6,000,000,000 || Entire project to be completed by 2023 |- | [[Victorian Desalination Plant]] || Williamsons Beach, [[Dalyston]]-[[Wonthaggi]], [[Bass Coast Shire]], [[Victoria (Australia)|Victoria]] || {{Yes|Completed}} || $4,000,000,000 || Built to provide more drinking water to [[Melbourne]] because in the mid-2000s the city's water reserves were at 28% of capacity. |} ====[[New Zealand]]==== {| class="sortable wikitable" |- ! Project !! City/Country !! Status !! Cost !! Special Notes |- | [[Christchurch|Rebuilding of Christchurch]] || [[New Zealand]] || {{Partial | Re-Construction In Progress}} || $17,000,000,000 || Recovery from [[Christchurch#2010–2012 earthquakes|earthquakes in 2010–2011]]. Rebuild of central business district, demolition and remediation of several residential neighbourhoods now deemed unsuitable for building. Infrastructure upgrades and addition of commuter rail. Entire project to be completed by 2020. |} ===[[South America]] ([[Latin America]])=== ====[[Brazil]]==== {| class="sortable wikitable" |- ! Project !! City/Country !! Status !! Cost !! Special Notes |- | [[Brasília]] || [[Brasília]] || {{yes|Completed}} || $21,900,000,000 || At the close of the 20th century, Brasília held the distinction of being the largest city in the world which had not existed at the beginning of the century.[http://salebatterymart.over-blog.com/article-brasilia-and-asuncion-110994606.html Brasília in the World] {{en icon}} Construction cost for Brasília in 1957 was about $2.5 Billion.[http://riotimesonline.com/brazil-news/rio-travel/brasilia-50-years-as-the-capital/ Brasília, 50 Years as the Capital] {{en icon}} |} ====[[Colombia]]==== {| class="sortable wikitable" |- ! Project !! City/Country !! Status !! Cost !! Special Notes |- | [[Bogota Urban Renewal]] || [[Bogota]] || {{partial|Under Development}} || $50,000,000,000 || One of the most ambitious projects in Latin American history. Includes building over 60 skyscrapers, 500 highrises, 3 new CBDs, a subway system, and a [[smart city]] near [[Usaquén]]. The project is meant to establish Bogota as the financial, industrial, and technological capital of Latin America. |- |} ==Water-related== {{Expand section|date=May 2017}} {{main|List of transport megaprojects}} Ports, waterways, canals, and locks for Passenger Ships and Cargo Ships carrying passengers and cargo from country to country and islands nations are built as megaprojects ===[[Africa]]=== ====[[North Africa]]==== [[File:New_Suez_Canal.jpeg|thumb|right|350px|Old and New Suez Canal]] =====[[Egypt]]===== {| class="sortable wikitable" |- ! Project !! Province(s) !! Status !! Cost !! Special Notes |- | [[New Suez Canal]] || [[Ismailia Governorate|Ismailia]] and [[Suez Governorate|Suez]] || {{Yes | Completed}} || $8,400,000,000 || In August 2014, work started on expanding the [[Suez Canal]], dubbed the "[[New Suez Canal]]" was completed and opened on 6 August 2015. |- | [[Suez Canal]] || [[Ismailia Governorate|Ismailia]] and [[Suez Governorate|Suez]] || {{Yes | Completed}} || $1,725,950,238.22 || A man-made canal that connects the [[Mediterranean Sea]] with the [[Red Sea]] cost $100 million in 1869. |} ====[[West Africa]]==== =====[[Nigeria]]===== {| class="sortable wikitable" |- ! Project !! City/State !! Status !! Cost !! Special Notes |- | Badagry Deep Sea Port || [[Badagry]], [[Lagos State]] || {{Partial|Under Construction}} || $2,300,000,000 || Construction started in January 2016, and the project is expected to have a "soft Launch" in 2018.{{cite web|url=http://www.badagry-port.com/timeline.php|title=- badagry-port.com|website=www.badagry-port.com}}{{cite web|url=https://www.thisdaylive.com/index.php/2016/10/08/ambode-revs-up-2-3bn-badagry-deep-sea-port-project/|title=Ambode Revs up $2.3bn Badagry Deep Sea Port Project|first=Online|last=Editor|date=8 October 2016|publisher=}} |- | [[Lekki Port]] || [[Lekki]], [[Lagos State]] || {{Partial|Under Construction}} || $1,650,000,000 || The Port at Lekki is a new [[seaport]] in [[Lekki]], and construction commenced in 2015. The port is planned to be developed in phases to meet the growing demand; phase one is expected to be operational by 2018. The port is financed by private investors and a consortium of banks who have funded the project with $1.65 billion so far.{{Cite web | url=https://guardian.ng/business-services/maritime/contractor-pledges-to-deliver-1-65b-lekki-deep-seaport-in-41-months/ | title=Contractor pledges to deliver $1.65b Lekki deep seaport in 41 months | website=guardian.ng | language=en | publisher=The Guardian | date=20 May 2015 | author=Ebosele, Moses | access-date=2017-08-10}} |} ===[[Asia]]=== ====[[East Asia]]==== =====[[China]]===== {| class="sortable wikitable" |- ! Project !! City/District/Province !! Status !! Cost !! Special Notes |- | [[Three Gorges Dam]] || [[Sandouping]], [[Yiling District]], [[Yichang]], [[Hubei Province]] || {{Yes | Completed}} || $59,000,000,000 || The Yangtze River Project began in 1994 and was Completed in 2003. |- | [[South–North Water Transfer Project]] || South to North [[China]] || {{Partial | Under Construction}} || $79,000,000,000{{cite news|author-link=Gordon G. Chang|first=Gordon G.|last=Chang|url=https://www.worldaffairsjournal.org/blog/gordon-g-chang/china%E2%80%99s-water-crisis-made-worse-policy-failures|title=China’s Water Crisis Made Worse by Policy Failures|date=8 January 2014|newspaper=[[World Affairs]]|access-date=23 November 2018}} || No timeline to indicate a completion date of this project and no telling how much more the project will cost. |} =====[[Japan]]===== {| class="sortable wikitable" |- ! Project !! City/Country !! Status !! Cost !! Special Notes |- | [[Kamaishi, Iwate|Kamaishi Tsunami Protection Breakwater]] || [[Kamaishi, Iwate]] || {{Yes | Completed}} || $1,500,000,000 || Completed in March 2009, it soon became the [[tsunami barrier]] that failed to protect [[Kamaishi]] during the [[2011 Tōhoku earthquake and tsunami]]. |} ====[[South Asia]]==== =====[[Sri Lanka]]===== {| class="sortable wikitable" |- ! Project !! City/Country !! Status !! Cost !! Special Notes |- | [[Colombo Harbour | Colombo Harbour Expansion Project]] || [[Colombo, Sri Lanka|Colombo]] || {{Yes | Completed}} || $1,200,000,000 || Construction began in 2008 and completely finished on 8 August 2013. |} ====[[Southwest Asia]] (a.k.a. the [[Middle East]])==== =====Israel===== {| class="sortable wikitable" |- ! Project !! City/Country !! Status !! Cost !! Special Notes |- | [[National Water Carrier of Israel]] || || {{Yes|Completed}} || ~$1,100,000,000 || Completed in 1956 |} =====[[United Arab Emirates]]===== {| class="sortable wikitable" |- ! Project !! City/Country !! Status !! Cost !! Special Notes |- | [[Dubai Marina]] || [[Dubai]] || {{Yes|Completed}} || || World's largest man-made [[marina]], with 200 residential and hotel high rises. |- | [[Dubai Waterfront]] || [[Dubai]] || {{Partial|Suspended}} || || Expected to become the largest waterfront and largest man-made development in the world. |} ===[[Caribbean]] ([[Latin America]])=== ====[[Cuba]]==== {| class="sortable wikitable" |- ! Project !! City/Province(s) !! Status !! Cost !! Special Notes |- | [[Mariel, Cuba|New Port of Mariel Development Project]] || [[Mariel, Cuba|Mariel]], [[Artemisa Province|Artemisa]] || {{Yes | Completed}} || $900,000,000{{Cite web | url=http://edition.cnn.com/2013/11/20/business/cuba-libre-could-new-port-communist/index.html | title=Cuba libre: Could port herald new economic age for communist island? | publisher=edition.cnn.com | date=November 20, 2013 | author=Macguire, Eoghan | access-date=2017-08-14}} || Though the project falls $100 million short of the billion dollar mark, it still counts as mega project for [[Cuba]] the first of many in 50+ years. |} ===[[Central America]] ([[Latin America]])=== ====[[Nicaragua]]==== {| class="sortable wikitable" |- ! Project !! City/Province(s) !! Status !! Cost !! Special Notes |- | [[Nicaragua Canal]] || || {{Dunno|Proposed}} || est. $100,000,000,000 || Formally the '''Nicaraguan Canal and Development Project''' (also referred to as the '''Nicaragua Grand Canal''', or the '''Grand Interoceanic Canal''') is a planned [[shipping route]] through [[Nicaragua]] to connect the [[Caribbean Sea]] (and therefore the [[Atlantic Ocean]]) with the [[Pacific Ocean]]. Its viability has been questioned by shipping experts and engineers{{cite news | last= McDonald | first= Michael D | title= China Slowdown Not Holding Back Nicaragua Canal, Contractor Says | publisher= BloombergBusiness | date= March 17, 2016 | url= https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-03-17/china-slowdown-not-holding-back-nicaragua-canal-contractor-says | accessdate= 21 March 2016}} |} [[File:New_Panama_Canal_expansion_project.png|thumbnail|350px|New Panama Canal expansion project. July 2015]] ====[[Panama]]==== {| class="sortable wikitable" |- ! Project !! Province(s) !! Status !! Cost !! Special Notes |- | [[Panama Canal]] || [[Colón Province]] and [[Panamá Province]] || {{Yes | Completed}} || $8,961,664,698.46 || Originally constructed by the United States for about $360 million. Opened on 15 August 1914 with a series of locks, canals, and lakes which connect ships traveling between the Atlantic Ocean and the Pacific Ocean. |- | [[Panama Canal Expansion]] || [[Colón Province]] and [[Panamá Province]] || {{Yes | Completed}} || $5,250,000,000 || The Expansion Opened 26 June 2016. |} ===[[Europe]]=== ====[[Netherlands]]==== {| class="sortable wikitable" |- ! Project !! City/Country !! Status !! Cost !! Special Notes |- | [[Zuiderzee Works]] || Central || || || A man-made system of [[dams]] and [[Levee|dikes]], [[land reclamation]] and water drainage work, in total the largest [[hydraulic engineering]] project undertaken by the [[Netherlands]] during the twentieth century. |- | [[Delta Works]] || Southwest || || || A series of construction projects in the southwest of the [[Netherlands]] to protect a large area of land around the [[Rhine-Meuse-Scheldt delta]] from the sea. |} ===[[North America]]=== ====[[Canada]]==== {| class="sortable wikitable" |- ! Project !! City/Province !! Status !! Cost !! Special Notes |- | [[Rideau Canal]] || [[Kingston, Ontario|Kingston]] to [[Ottawa]] || {{Yes | Completed}} || £822,804 (January 1834) || A 202 km waterway opened in 1832 to provide a secure supply and communications route between Montreal and the British naval base in Kingston. |} ====[[Mexico]] ([[Latin America]])==== {| class="sortable wikitable" |- ! Project !! City/State !! Status !! Cost !! Special Notes |- | [[Port of Veracruz Expansion]] || [[Veracruz]] || {{Partial | Under Construction}} || $5,000,000,000 || |} ====[[United States]]==== {| class="sortable wikitable" |- ! Project !! City/State !! Status !! Cost !! Special Notes |- | [[Intracoastal Waterway]] || [[Boston, Massachusetts]] to [[Brownsville, Texas]] || || || A 3,000-mile (4,800 km) [[inland waterway]] along the [[Atlantic]] and [[Gulf of Mexico]] coasts of the United States, running from [[Boston, Massachusetts]], southward along the Atlantic Seaboard and around the southern tip of [[Florida]], then following the Gulf Coast to [[Brownsville, Texas]]. |} ===[[South America]] ([[Latin America]])=== ====[[Brazil]]==== {| class="sortable wikitable" |- ! Project !! City/Country !! Status !! Cost !! Special Notes |- | [[Porto Maravilha]] || [[Rio de Janeiro]] || {{Yes | Completed}} || $35,700,000,000 || Entire project to be completed by 2015. |} ==See also== * [[List of most expensive U.S. public works projects]] ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==External links== * [http://www.losapos.com/dubai%20mega-projects Megaprojects in Dubai] {{DEFAULTSORT:Megaprojects}} [[Category:Engineering projects|*]] [[Category:Lists of most expensive things]] [[Category:Megaprojects]]

revision.text:
{{refimprove|date=January 2017}} {{Infobox Government agency |agency_name = [[Kingdom of Thailand]]
Ministry of Science and Technology |type = Ministry |abbreviation = |nativename = กระทรวงวิทยาศาสตร์และเทคโนโลยี |logo = |logo_width = |logo_caption = |seal = |seal_width = |seal_caption = |formed = {{Start date and age|df=y|2002|10|03}} |preceding1 = |dissolved = |superseding = Ministry of Higher Education and Research and Development |jurisdiction = [[Government of Thailand]] |headquarters = [[Ratchathewi District|Ratchathewi]], [[Bangkok]] |coordinates = |employees = |budget = 14,885.4 million baht (FY2019) |minister1_name = Suvit Maesincee |minister1_pfo =Minister |child1_agency = |child2_agency = |website = {{url|http://www.most.go.th/main/en/}} |footnotes = }} The '''Ministry of Science and Technology''' ({{lang-th|กระทรวงวิทยาศาสตร์และเทคโนโลยี}}; {{RTGS|''krasuang witthaya sat lae theknoloyi''}}; [[Abbreviation|Abrv:]] MOST), is a [[Thailand|Thai]] government body responsible for the oversight of [[science and technology in Thailand]]. ==Background== ===Creation=== The Ministry of Science, Technology and Environment (MoSTE) was a [[Government of Thailand|Thai government]] [[Ministry (government department)|ministry]] from 1992 until 2002.{{cite web|title=Overview of the Ministry of Science and Technology |url=http://www.most.go.th/eng/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=84&Itemid=488 |website=Ministry of Science and Technology |publisher=Government of Thailand |accessdate=9 February 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160216172041/https://www.most.go.th/eng/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=84&Itemid=488 |archivedate=16 February 2016 |df= }} With the coming into effect of the Restructuring of Government Agencies Act of 2002, the ministry was reorganized into the following separate ministries:{{cite web|url=http://www.most.go.th/eng/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2012-02-06 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120201045341/http://www.most.go.th/eng/ |archivedate=2012-02-01 |df= }} * Ministry of Science and Technology * [[Ministry of Energy (Thailand)|Ministry of Energy]] * [[Ministry of Natural Resources and Environment (Thailand)|Ministry of Natural Resources and Environment]] ===Dissolution=== On 24 October 2018, the Thai cabinet approved the creation of a Ministry of Higher Education and Research & Development. The new ministry will merge the '''Science and Technology Ministry''', the Office of the Higher Education Commission (OHEC), the National Research Council of Thailand, and the Thailand Research Fund. The current Minister of Science and Technology, Suvit Maesincee, will head the new ministry. Its mission will be "...to develop high technology, enhancing the efficiency of the R&D and support Thailand 4.0 policy, as well as human resource development." The government has allotted a 97 billion [[Thai baht|baht]] budget to the new ministry in its first year, [[Fiscal year|FY2019]].{{cite news |last1=Theparat |first1=Chatrudee |title=New hybrid ministry approved |url=https://www.bangkokpost.com/business/news/1563922/new-hybrid-ministry-approved?utm_source=enewsletter_alert&utm_medium=email&utm_term=business |accessdate=25 October 2018 |work=Bangkok Post |date=25 October 2018}} ==Budget== The ministry's budget for FY2019 is 14,885.4 million baht.{{cite book |title=Thailand's Budget in Brief Fiscal Year 2019 |date=September 2018 |publisher=Bureau of the Budget |page=82 |url=http://www.bb.go.th/en/topic-detail.php?id=8322&mid=456&catID=0 |accessdate=25 October 2018}} == Organization== === Administration === * Office of the Minister * Office of the Permanent Secretary * [[Office of Atoms for Peace]] * Department of Science Service (DSS){{cite news|last1=Suksamran|first1=Nauvarat|title=It's not just the pretty packaging|url=https://www.bangkokpost.com/news/general/1463634/its-not-just-the-pretty-packaging|accessdate=12 May 2018|work=Bangkok Post|date=12 May 2018}} === Dependent departments === * [[National Science and Technology Development Agency]] * National Institute of Metrology * National Science Technology and Innovation Policy Office === State enterprises === * [[Thailand Institute of Scientific and Technological Research]] * [[National Science Museum (Thailand)|National Science Museum]] === Public Organization === * [[Geo-Informatics and Space Technology Development Agency]] * [[National Astronomical Research Institute of Thailand]] * National Innovation Agency * [[Thailand Institute of Nuclear Technology]] * Synchrotron Light Research Institute * Hydro and Agro Informatics Institute * [[Thailand Center of Excellence for Life Sciences]] ==See also== * [[List of government ministries of Thailand]] ==References== {{Reflist}} {{ThaiCabinetDept}} [[Category:Government ministries of Thailand|Science and Technology]] [[Category:Science and technology in Thailand]] [[Category:Science and technology ministries|Thailand]] [[Category:2002 establishments in Thailand]] revision.text:
{{Nanoelec}}A '''nanoradio''' (also called carbon nanotube radio) is a nanotechnology acting as a radio transmitter and receiver by using [[carbon nanotube]]s. One of the first nanoradios was constructed in 2007 by researchers under [[Alex Zettl]] at the [[University of California, Berkeley]] where they successfully transmitted an audio signal.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=http://www.berkeley.edu/news/media/releases/2007/10/31_NanoRadio.shtml|title=10.31.2007 - Single nanotube makes world's smallest radio|website=www.berkeley.edu|access-date=2016-11-05}}</ref> Due to the small size, nanoradios can have several possible applications such as radio function in the bloodstream.<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|last=Regis|first=Ed|date=2009-01-01|title=The World's Smallest Radio|url=http://www.nature.com/scientificamerican/journal/v300/n3/full/scientificamerican0309-40.html|journal=Scientific American|language=en|volume=300|issue=3|pages=40–45|doi=10.1038/scientificamerican0309-40}}</ref>
== History == The first observation of a nanoradio can be accredited to a Japanese physicist [[Sumio Iijima]] in 1991 who saw a "a luminous discharge of electricity" coming from a carbon nanotube on a graphite electrode.<ref name=":0" /> On October 31, 2007, a team of researchers under Alex Zettl at the University of California, Berkeley created one of the first nanoradios.<ref name=":1" /> Their experiment consisted of placing a multilayered nanotube placed on a silicon electrode and connecting it to a counter electrode through a wire and a DC battery. Both the electrode and nanotube were also put in a vacuum of about 10<sup>−7</sup> Torr.<ref name=":2">{{Cite web|url=http://www2.lbl.gov/tt/publications/2431.pdf|title=Nanotube Radio|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=K. Jensen, J. Weldon, H. Garcia, and A. Zettl|access-date=}}</ref> They then placed the apparatus into a [[High-resolution transmission electron microscopy|high-resolution transmission electron microscope]] to document the movement of the nanotube. They observed the nanoradio vibrating and transmitted a song called "Layla" by Eric Clapton.<ref>{{Citation|last=Chemistry World|title=Real single nanotube radio plays Layla|date=2007-11-01|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=htpCovoRtn0|accessdate=2016-10-24}}</ref> After some minor adjustments, the team was able to transmit and receive signals from a couple meters across the laboratory;<ref name=":0" /> however, the initial audio receptions from the radio were scratchy which Zettl believed was due to the lack of a better vacuum.<ref name=":1" />
== Properties == The small size, roughly 10 nanometers wide and hundreds of nanometers long, and composition of nanoradios provide several distinct properties. The small size of nanoradios enables electrons to pass through without much friction, making nanoradios efficient conductors. Nanoradios can also come in different sizes; they can be double-walled, tripled-walled and multi-walled. Aside from the different sizes, nanoradios can also take different shapes such as bent, straight or [[toroid]]al. Common among all nanoradios is how relatively strong they are. The resistance can be attributed to the strength of the bonds between carbon atoms.<ref name=":0" />
== Function == The fundamental parts of a radio are the antenna, tuner, demodulator and amplifier. Carbon nanotubes are special in that they can function as these parts without the need of extra circuitry.
=== Antenna === The nanoradio is small enough for electromagnetic signals to mechanically vibrate the nanoradio. The nanoradio essentially acts as an antenna by vibrating with the same frequency as the signal from incoming electromagnetic waves; this is in contrast with traditional radio antennas, which are generally stationary.<ref name=":2" /> The nanotube can vibrate in high frequencies, from "thousands to millions of times per second." <ref name=":1" />
=== Tuner === The nanoradio can also function as a tuner by extending or reducing the length of the nanotube; doing so changes the resonance frequency at which it vibrates, enabling the radio to tune into specific frequencies. The length of the nanotube can be extended by pulling the tip with a positive electrode and can be shortened by removing atoms off the tip.<ref name=":1" /> Consequently, changing the length is permanent and can't be reversed; however, the method of varying the electric field can also affect the frequency that the nanoradio responds without being permanent.<ref name=":0" />
=== Amplifier === As a benefit of the microscopic size and needle-like shape, the nanoradio functions naturally as an [[amplifier]]. The nanoradio exhibits [[Field electron emission|field emission]], in which a small voltage emits a flow of electrons; due to this, a small electromagnetic wave would produce a large flow of electrons, amplifying the signal.<ref name=":0" />
=== Demodulator === [[Demodulation]] is essentially the separation of the information signal from the carrier wave. When the nanoradio vibrates in sync with the carrier wave, the nanoradio responds only to the information signal and ignores the [[carrier wave]]; and so, the nanoradio can act as a demodulator without the need of circuitry.<ref name=":0" />
== Medical Application == Currently, chemotherapy uses chemicals that harm not only cancerous cells, but also healthy ones since they are put into the blood stream. Nanoradios can be used to prevent damage to healthy cells by remotely communicating with the radio to release drugs and specifically target cancerous cells. Nanoradios can also be injected into individual cells to release certain chemicals, enabling repair of specific cells.<ref name=":0" /> Nanoradios can also be used to monitor insulin levels of diabetes patients and use that information to release a drug or chemical.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www2.technologyreview.com/news/409595/tr10-nanoradio/2/|title=TR10: NanoRadio - MIT Technology Review|last=Service|first=Robert F.|newspaper=MIT Technology Review|access-date=2016-11-05}}</ref>
== Complications == The implanting of nanoradios in the body are currently not feasible due to power dissipation. The nanoradio radiates about 4.5 x 10<sup>−27</sup> W of electromagnetic power; however, much of this power would be loss when passing through the body. The amount of energy input can be increased, but would generate too much heat in the body, posing a safety risk. Other issues include the difficulty of constructing a nanoradio due to its nanoscale size, requiring quantum models and precision to manufacture.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Diaz|first=R. E.|last2=Sebastian|first2=T.|date=2013-12-18|title=Electromagnetic limits to radiofrequency (RF) neuronal telemetry|journal=Scientific Reports|volume=3|doi=10.1038/srep03535|issn=2045-2322|pmc=3866607|pmid=24346503}}</ref>
== References == {{reflist}}
[[Category:Nanoelectronics]] [[Category:Radio technology]] [[Category:Radio electronics]]

{{ one source|date=January 2013}} '''Online hotel reservations''' are a popular method for booking [[hotel]] rooms. [[Travel]]ers can book rooms on a computer by using [[Transport Layer Security|online security]] to protect their privacy and financial information and by using several online [[travel agent]]s to compare prices and facilities at different hotels.
Prior to the [[Internet]], travelers could write, telephone the hotel directly, or use a travel agent to make a reservation. Nowadays, online travel agents have pictures of hotels and rooms, information on prices and deals, and even information on local [[resorts]]. Many also allow [[review]]s of the traveler to be recorded with the online travel agent.
Online hotel reservations are also helpful for making last minute travel arrangements. Hotels may drop the price of a room if some rooms are still available. There are several [[websites]] that specialize in searches for deals on rooms.
==Connections to air travel== Large hotel chains typically have direct connections to the airline national distribution systems ([[Computer reservations system|GDS]]) ([[Sabre (computer system)|Sabre]], [[Galileo (computer system)|Galileo]], [[Amadeus (computer system)|Amadeus]], and [[Worldspan]]). These in turn provide hotel information directly to the hundreds of thousands of travel agents that align themselves with one of these systems. Individual hotels and small hotel chains often cannot afford the expense of these direct connections and turn to other companies to provide the connections.<ref name="hotel-online.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.hotel-online.com/News/PR2001_1st/Mar01_ResvSvcs.html|title=Choosing a Reservation Representation Company|accessdate=2010-05-27}}</ref>
==Large-scale travel sites== Several large online travel sites are, in effect, travel agencies. These sites send the hotels' information and rates downstream to literally thousands of online travel sites, most of which act as travel agents. They can then receive commission payments from the hotels for any business booked on their websites.
==Individual hotel websites== An increasing number of hotels are building their own websites to allow them to market their hotels directly to consumers. Non-franchise chain hotels require a "booking engine" application to be attached to their website to permit people to book rooms in real time. One advantage of booking with the hotel directly is the use of the hotel's full cancellation policy as well as not needing a deposit in most situations.<ref name="hotel-online.com"/> <ref>{{cite news|title=Hotel Reservations|url=http://www.reservations.com/stay|accessdate=23 June 2016|work=reservations}}</ref>
The online booking engine applications are supported by [[Content management system]](CMS).
==Database systems== To improve the likelihood of filling rooms, hotels tend to use several of the above systems. The content on many [[hotel reservation systems]] is becoming increasingly similar as more hotels sign up to all the sites. Companies thus have to either rely on specially negotiated rates with the hotels and hotel chains or trust in the influence of search engine rankings to draw in customers.
==See also== * [[Travel technology]]
==References== {{reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Online Hotel Reservations}} [[Category:Travel technology]]

{{distinguish|living hinge}} [[File:plastic hinges.jpg|thumb|300px|Diagram of a structure featuring plastic hinges]]
In the [[structural engineering]] [[beam theory]] term, plastic hinge, is used to describe the deformation of a section of a [[Beam (structure)|beam]] where [[plastic bending]] occurs.<ref>{{Cite book | edition = 2 | publisher = Butterworth-Heinemann | isbn = 0-7506-6221-2 | last = Megson | first = T.H.G. | title = Structural and Stress Analysis, Second Edition | date = 2005-04-29 }}</ref> In [[earthquake engineering]] '''plastic hinge''' is also a type of energy [[damping]] device allowing [[Plasticity (physics)|plastic]] rotation [deformation] of an otherwise rigid column connection.<ref>[http://mceer.buffalo.edu/education/reu/04Proceedings/12Long_Bergad.pdf Analysis of Rotational Column with Plastic Hinge] Michael Long and Corey Bergad, retrieved November 5, 2006</ref>
==Plastic behaviour== In plastic [[Limit state design|limit analysis]] of structural members subjected to bending, it is assumed that an abrupt transition from elastic to ideally plastic behaviour occurs at a certain value of moment, known as [[Plastic Moment|plastic moment]] (M<sub>p</sub>). Member behaviour between M<sub>yp</sub> and M<sub>p</sub> is considered to be elastic. When M<sub>p</sub> is reached, a plastic hinge is formed in the member. In contrast to a [[friction]]less hinge permitting free rotation, it is postulated that the plastic hinge allows large rotations to occur at constant plastic moment M<sub>p</sub>.
Plastic hinges extend along short lengths of beams. Actual values of these lengths depend on cross-sections and load distributions. But detailed analyses have shown that it is sufficiently accurate to consider beams rigid-plastic, with plasticity confined to plastic hinges at points. While this assumption is sufficient for [[Limit state design|limit state analysis]], finite element formulations are available to account for the spread of plasticity along plastic hinge lengths.<ref>{{cite journal | doi = 10.1061/(ASCE)0733-9445(2006)132:2(244) | volume=132 | title=Plastic Hinge Integration Methods for Force-Based Beam–Column Elements | year=2006 | journal=Journal of Structural Engineering | pages=244–252 | last1 = Scott | first1 = Michael H. | last2 = Fenves | first2 = Gregory L.}}</ref>
By inserting a plastic hinge at a plastic limit load into a statically determinate beam, a kinematic mechanism permitting an unbounded displacement of the system can be formed. It is known as the collapse mechanism. For each degree of static indeterminacy of the beam, an additional plastic hinge must be added to form a collapse mechanism
Sufficient number of plastic hinges(N) required to make a collapse mechanism (unstable structure):
N=Degree of static indeterminacy + 1
==References== <references/>
[[Category:Building engineering]] [[Category:Structural engineering]]

revision.text:
The '''Scanning Multichannel Microwave Radiometer (SMMR)''' [pronounced ''simmer''] was a five-frequency [[microwave radiometer]] flown on the [[Seasat]] and [[Nimbus program|Nimbus 7]] satellites. Both were launched in 1978, with the Seasat mission lasting less than six months until failure of the primary [[Electrical cable|bus]]. The Nimbus 7 SMMR lasted from 25 October 1978 until 20 August 1987. It measured dual-polarized microwave radiances, at 6.63, 10.69, 18.0, 21.0, and 37.0 GHz, from the Earth's atmosphere and surface. Its primary legacy has been the creation of areal [[sea-ice]] climatologies for the Arctic and Antarctic.
The final few months of operation was considerably fortuitous as it allowed the calibration of the radiometers and their products with the first results from the [[Special Sensor Microwave/Imager|SSMI]].
==References== Jezek, K.C., C. Merry, D. Cavalieri, S.Grace, J. Bedner, D. Wilson and D. Lampkin 1991: Comparison between SMMR and SSM/I passive microwave data collected over the Antarctic Ice Sheet. Byrd Polar Research Center, The Ohio State university, Columbus, OH., BPRC Technical Report Number 91-03, {{ISSN|1056-8050}}.
==External links== * http://nsidc.org/data/nsidc-0071.html * https://web.archive.org/web/20060930044535/http://podaac.jpl.nasa.gov:2031/SENSOR_DOCS/smmr.html * http://ieeexplore.ieee.org/xpls/abs_all.jsp?isnumber=25768&arnumber=1145458&type=ref
[[Category:Satellite meteorology and remote sensing]] [[Category:Radiometry]] [[Category:Spacecraft instruments]]

{{Refimprove|date=January 2016}} [[File:Dmm 240cm dyneema sling.jpg|right|thumb|A {{Convert|240|cm}} Sling]] [[File:Climing anchor.JPG|thumb|right|A [[Anchor (climbing)|climbing anchor]] equalized using dyneema slings.]]
A '''sling''' or '''runner''' is an item of [[climbing equipment]] consisting of a tied or sewn loop of [[webbing]]. These can be wrapped around sections of rock, [[hitch knot|hitched]] to other pieces of equipment, or tied directly to a tensioned line using a [[Prusik]] style knot. They may be used as [[Climbing_equipment#Protection_devices|anchors]], to extend an anchor to reduce [[rope drag]], in anchor equalization, or to climb a rope.<ref name="freedom">{{cite book | edition = 7 | editor = Cox, Steven M. |editor2=Kris Fulsaas, ed. | title = [[Mountaineering: The Freedom of the Hills]] | publisher = The Mountaineers | ISBN = 0-89886-828-9| location = Seattle | year = 2003-09}}</ref>
==Types== [[File:Conn - The versatile runner - Summit Nov 1957.pdf|thumb|left|Early article on use of slings by [[Jan and Herb Conn]].]] Slings come both sewn to length and assembled from loose webbing knotted as desired. Common sewn lengths include {{Convert|10|cm}}, {{Convert|30|cm}}, {{Convert|60|cm}}, {{Convert|120|cm}} and {{Convert|240|cm}}. They are available in widths of {{Convert|6|–|20|mm}}. Webbing for slings, also known as ''tape'', is sold off the reel, cut to length with a hot knife to prevent fraying, and tied as desired with a [[water knot]].
Sewn slings have a rated breaking strength of at least {{Convert|22|kN}}. Short sewn slings are a component of [[quickdraw]]s, sometimes known as ''dogbones''.
Traditionally, slings have been made of [[nylon]]. Increasingly, [[ultra high molecular weight polyethylene]] sold under the brand names Dyneema, Dynex and Spectra is used. These have much lower melting points than nylon, making them a potentially poor choice where high rope friction may occur. However this specialty polyethylene is lighter, smaller, and absorbs less water than nylon, and therefore has become popular.
==Gear sling== A '''gear sling''' is a loop of webbing used to organize or carry equipment. These can be custom items meant only to carry light gear, fully load-bearing manufactured gear racks capable of doubling for a sling, or simply a regular sling used to rack gear.
==See also== * [[Climbing equipment#Daisy chain|Daisy Chain]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[https://ledtexwebbing.com/ Ledtex Webbing]
[[Category:Climbing equipment]] [[Category:Mountaineering equipment]]
{{Climbing-nav}}

{{for|the boatbuilding technique|Spiling (boat building)}} [[File:Spiling pics 005.jpg|thumb|right|Willow spiling in Wales]] <!-- [[File:Spiling 115239.JPG|thumb|Spiling seen in the outer moat (now drained) of [[Tilbury Fort]]]] --> '''Spiling''' is a traditional technique used in temperate regions of the world for the prevention of erosion to river and stream banks.
[[Willow]] spiling is currently used in the United Kingdom; live willow rods are woven between live willow uprights and the area behind is filled with soil for the willow to root into.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://evidence.environment-agency.gov.uk/FCERM/en/SC060065/MeasuresList/M5/M5T6.aspx?pagenum=2|title=Managing bank instability and erosion|publisher=Environment Agency (UK)|accessdate=20 October 2013}}</ref>
[[Rudyard Kipling|Kipling]]'s poem ''The Land'' mentions it: "They spiled along the water-course with trunks of willow-trees, And planks of elms behind 'em and immortal oaken knees."<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.kipling.org.uk/poems_land.htm |title=The Land |first=Rudyard |last=Kipling |year=1917 |publisher=The Kipling Society |accessdate=3 November 2013}}</ref>
The species of [[willow]] used are riparian (associated with rivers); the posts, {{convert|10|cm|in|0}} in diameter, are usually ''[[Salix alba]]'' or ''[[Salix fragilis|S. fragilis]]'', and ''[[Salix viminalis|S. viminalis]]'' varieties are used for the interwoven rods. The living willow posts are driven into the bank, to a depth of {{convert|30|cm|ft|0}} or more, at {{convert|60|cm|ft|0|adj=on}} intervals and the thinner rods are woven in between, the rods are best woven at an angle slightly above horizontal to ensure good survival rates. A row of stones, gabions or wooden planks held by posts can be added to the bottom of each "spile" to prevent undercutting when the willow is establishing itself. All works should be done during the dormant period, winter in temperate zones. A layer of seeded [[coir]] matting can be pegged onto the soil on top of the spiles to prevent the soil being washed out during flood events. This method is an example of [[soft engineering]], techniques which tend to be less expensive and more sustainable than others. <ref>{{cite web |title=Manual of River Restoration Techniques |url=http://www.therrc.co.uk/rrc_manual.php |publisher=River Restoration Centre |accessdate=3 November 2013}}</ref>
== See also == * [[Fascine]]
== References == {{Commons category}} {{reflist}}
[[Category:Environmental engineering]]
{{Civil-engineering-stub}}

'''Suitability Analysis''' is the process and procedures used to establish the suitability of a [[system]] - that is, the ability of a system to meet the needs of a [[Project stakeholder|stakeholder]] or other [[user (system)|user]].
Before GIS (a computerized method that helps to determine suitability analysis) was widely used in the mid to late 20th century, city planners communicated their suitability analysis ideas by laying transparencies in increasing darkness over maps of the present conditions. This technique's descendant is used in a GIS application called multicriteria decision analysis.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Malczewski|first=Jacek|date=2004-07-01|title=GIS-based land-use suitability analysis: a critical overview|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0305900603000801|journal=Progress in Planning|volume=62|issue=1|pages=3–65|doi=10.1016/j.progress.2003.09.002}}</ref> In the 1960s, a mechanism called the ecological inventory process was developed to document existing surrounding land conditions to help inform the analysis for the land in question. These mechanisms were computerized upon the advent of computers due to inefficiencies in the methods, such as the inability to overlay a large number of transparencies.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Collins|first=Michael G.|last2=Steiner|first2=Frederick R.|last3=Rushman|first3=Michael J.|date=2001-11-01|title=Land-Use Suitability Analysis in the United States: Historical Development and Promising Technological Achievements|url=https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s002670010247|journal=Environmental Management|language=en|volume=28|issue=5|pages=611–621|doi=10.1007/s002670010247|issn=0364-152X}}</ref>
In order to feed a growing population that is pushing on the ability to extensively farm, suitability analysis is becoming more necessary to utilize the most productive land to its fullest potential, matching the needs of the plants more carefully to the existing assets in the environment. This technique is known as precision farming.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.itc.nl/library/Papers_2003/msc/gfm/prakash.pdf|title=Land Suitability Analysis for Agricultural Crops: A Fuzzy Multicriteria Decision Making Approach|last=Prakash|first=T. N.|date=2003|website=University of Twente|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
Suitability analysis can also be used to track and label potential hazards, like earthquakes, contamination, or even crime. It can also be used to locate advantageous locations for commercial centers.<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|last=Hopkins|first=Lewis D.|date=1977-10-01|title=Methods for Generating Land Suitability Maps: A Comparative Evaluation|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1080/01944367708977903|journal=Journal of the American Institute of Planners|volume=43|issue=4|pages=386–400|doi=10.1080/01944367708977903|issn=0002-8991}}</ref>
== Suitability in GIS context ==
'''Suitability analysis''' in a GIS context is a geographic, or [[Geographic information system|GIS]]-based process used to determine the appropriateness of a given area for a particular use. The basic premise of GIS suitability analysis is that each aspect of the landscape has [[Intrinsic and extrinsic properties|intrinsic]] characteristics that are to some degree either suitable or unsuitable for the activities being planned. Suitability is determined through systematic, multi-factor analysis of the different aspects of the terrain.<ref>Michael D. Murphy (2005) ''[http://www.public.iastate.edu/~fridolph/images/la567/MichaelDMurphy_2005_LandscapeArchitecturalTheory_Suitability3.pdf Landscape Architectural Theory]''</ref> Model inputs include a variety of physical, cultural, and economic factors. The results are often displayed on a map that is used to highlight areas from high to low suitability.<ref>James A. LaGro ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=ro11E5Cv-n0C&printsec=frontcover&source=gbs_v2_summary_r&cad=0 Site Analysis]''</ref>
A GIS suitability model typically answers the question, "Where is the best location?" — whether it involves finding the best location for a new road or pipeline, a new housing development, or a retail store. For instance, a commercial developer building a new retail store may take into consideration distance to major highways and any competitors' stores, then combine the results with [[land use]], population density, and consumer spending data to decide on the best location for that store. <ref>''[http://www.esri.com/library/brochures/pdfs/spatialanalystbro.pdf Spatial Analyst]''</ref>
=== GIS Applications ===
* '''Land use analysis''': Land-use suitability analysis requires the use of GIS (Geographic Information Systems) in order to survey geographical suitability. This process can be viewed through the techno-positivist and the socio-political, public engagement perspectives. Within the analysis of suitability there are also needed factors regarding economic opportunity costs and social implications within particular areas of land. There has been critique in the role that both of these aspects of careful spatial planning entail.<ref>Malczewski, Jacek. "GIS-based land-use suitability analysis: a critical overview." Progress in planning 62.1 (2004): 3-65. Suitability analysis for enhancing wildlife habitat in the Yolo Basin Jones & Stokes Associates.; Central Valley Habitat Joint Venture.; California Wetlands Foundation.1994</ref>The instrumental approach to spatial analysis can either be seen as a tool, or as a main plan when it comes to suitability. This brings up the theoretical questions of space, place, and the social construction of both. Land-Use suitability requires a multicriteria analysis, which is allows assumptive and theoretical mapping to become actualized.<ref>Ascough, J. C., Rector, H. D., Hoag, D. L., McMaster, G. S., Vandenberg, B. C., Shaffer, M. J., Weltz, M. A., and Ahuja, L. R., “Multicriteria Spatial Decision Support Systems: Overview, Applications, and Future Research Directions,” Proc. Integrated Assessment and Decision Support, 175 (2002).</ref>Most jurisdictions use land suitability analysis for site selection, impact studies, and land use planning.<ref>Edward J. Kaiser, David R. Godschalk, and F. Stuart Chapin, Jr. ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=3vvEYWMtcMYC&printsec=frontcover&source=gbs_v2_summary_r&cad=0 Urban land use planning]''</ref> * '''Retail site selection''': Suitability analysis is critical for both marketing and merchandising purposes, as well as for choosing new retail locations.<ref>Ela Dramowicz (2005) ''[http://www.directionsmag.com/article.php?article_id=896 Retail Trade Area Analysis Using the Huff Model]''</ref> * '''Agriculture''' * '''Defense''' * '''Crime analysis''' * '''Town Planning''' * '''Wildlife''': The identification of physical structuresnatural habitats, and the relationship between the two and the environmental impacts of that. This allows for the optimization between the relationship of enhancing wildlife while also allowing for man made development.<ref>Malczewski, Jacek. "GIS-based land-use suitability analysis: a critical overview." Progress in planning 62.1 (2004): 3-65. Suitability analysis for enhancing wildlife habitat in the Yolo Basin Jones & Stokes Associates.; Central Valley Habitat Joint Venture.; California Wetlands Foundation.1994</ref>
== Possibility Space ==
'''The Possibility Space''' is a framework that allows for the analysis of all possible consequences and benefits of a suitability analysis. This is created through geometrical data analysis conducted in real time with technological land mapping, allowing for the development of multiple combinations of suitability. Physically it is a visual interactive database that allows for a holistic composition of suitability.<ref>Wutthigrai Boonsuk ; Chris Harding; Possibility space for GIS suitability analysis. Proc. SPIE 9017, Visualization and Data Analysis 2014, 90170R (December 23, 2013); doi:10.1117/12.2040165.</ref>
== Methods == * '''Gestalt method:''' The area is mapped and similar regions are identified. Additional maps are drawn for each homogeneous location representing each possible land use, which are compared and analyzed to ascertain the best possible land use. However, this method is not very commonly used because it requires intense knowledge of the place in question, usually only acquired when the planner has the opportunity to live in the space and dedicate an ample amount of time to it. It is also more difficult to communicate it effectively.<ref name=":0" /> * '''Ordinal combination method:''' The area is mapped according to qualities of the land, including slope, soil type, vegetation, climate, etc., and each quality has a rating associated with it corresponding to its value. Therefore, the land use is determined by the suitability rating given to it based on the comparable qualities of other areas.<ref name=":0" />Some shortfalls include that the rating is subjective to the expert, and each rating must be done on the same scale to be comparable. * '''Linear combination method:''' The rated qualities of the ordinal combination method are compared with different weights with the most weight put on the most important value and the least weight put on the least important, though each rating is put on the same interval scale. * '''Values suitability analysis:''' Human values (like aesthetic preferences, etc.) are taken into account with similar weight to quantifiable costs and benefits in deciding land suitability. This is done frequently in deciding incorporation of open spaces and their management techniques.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=REED|first=PATRICK|last2=BROWN|first2=GREGORY|date=2003-09-01|title=Values Suitability Analysis: A Methodology for Identifying and Integrating Public Perceptions of Ecosystem Values in Forest Planning|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1080/0964056032000138418|journal=Journal of Environmental Planning and Management|volume=46|issue=5|pages=643–658|doi=10.1080/0964056032000138418|issn=0964-0568}}</ref>
* '''[[Analytic hierarchy process|AHP (Analytic Hierarchy Process):]]''' A method that determines the weight of each component of the land making it favorable or unfavorable for each use. It has the capability to identify inconsistencies in judgement.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://citeseerx.ist.psu.edu/viewdoc/download?doi=10.1.1.468.4502&rep=rep1&type=pdf|title=Download Limit Exceeded|website=citeseerx.ist.psu.edu|access-date=2017-05-25}}</ref>
== Results == When suitability analyses are done, several different usability options may be found for the same section of land. This can be advantageous or limiting. If the land is found suitable for two or more uses that can be combined, the land uses are found compatible. An example of this may be a building with businesses on the bottom floor with residences on upper floors. Compatible land uses result in a win-win development; a need for more commerce is met while meeting a need for more housing, while also keeping people on the street all day, thereby reducing the probability of crime. Conflicting land use occurs when a piece of land can be used only for one use or the other. This is exemplified by a piece of land that can either be used as agricultural land or developed into a housing tract--should the land be developed, it can no longer be used for agriculture. The suitability analysis comes back into play here by helping planners prioritize which need is greater (in the case of the example, is housing or agricultural land more necessary in light of economic or demand pressure).<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nrs.fs.fed.us/pubs/gtr/other/gtr-nc205/pdffiles/p31.PDF|title=A GIS-BASED MULTICRITERIA APPROACHES TO LAND USE SUITABILITY ASSESSMENT AND ALLOCATION|last=Mendoza|first=Guillermo A.|date=June 1, 2017|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
==See also== * [[GIS]] * [[Spatial analysis]] * [[Geospatial predictive modeling]] * [[Environmental planning]]
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Geographic information systems]]
